entry.note: The form of G is from the Latin, in the alphabet which it first appeared as a modified form of C. The name is also from the Latin, and probably comes to us through the French. Etymologically it is most closely related to a c hard, k y, and w; as in corn, grain, kernel; kin L. genus, Gr. �; E. garden, yard; drag, draw; also to ch and h; as in get, prehensile; guest, host (an army); gall, choler; gust, choose. See C.

sn.def: G is the seventh letter of the English alphabet, and a vocal consonant. It has two sounds; one simple, as in gave go gull; the other compound (like that of j), as in gem gin dingy. See Guide to Pronunciation, §§ 231-6, 155, 176, 178, 179, 196, 211, 246.

G is the name of the fifth tone of the natural or model scale; -- called also sol by the Italians and French. It was also originally used as the treble clef, and has gradually changed into the character represented in the margin. See Clef. G♯ (G sharp) is a tone intermediate between G and A.

entry.ety: Cf. Gaff
entry.def: The hook on the end of an eccentric rod opposite the strap. See. Illust. of Eccentric.

cs.cd: facility of expression.

entry.ety: OE. gabbe gabble, mocking, fr. Icel. gabb mocking, mockery, or OF. gab gabe; perh. akin to E. gape, or gob. Cf. Gab v. i. Gibber
entry.def: The mouth; hence, idle prate; chatter; unmeaning talk; loquaciousness.

entry.ety: OE. gabben to jest, lie, mock, deceive, fr. Icel. gabba to mock, or OF. gaber. See 2d Gab, and cf. Gabble

sn.def: To deceive; to lie.
To talk idly; to prate; to chatter.

entry.def: A kind of coarse cloth for packing goods.

entry.ety: Sp. gabardina; cf. It. gavardina, OF. galvardine calvardine gavardine galeverdine; perh. akin to Sp. & OF. gaban a sort of cloak or coat for rainy weather, F. caban great coat with a hood and sleeves, It. gabbano and perh. to E. cabin
entry.def: A coarse frock or loose upper garment formerly worn by Jews; a mean dress.

sn.def: A liar; a deceiver.
One addicted to idle talk.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Gabbled; p. pr. & vb. n. Gabbling
entry.ety: Freq. of gab. See Gab v. i.

sn.def: To talk fast, or to talk without meaning; to prate; to jabber.
To utter inarticulate sounds with rapidity; -- used of fowls as well as people; as, gabbling geese.
Loud or rapid talk without meaning.
sn.q: Forthwith a hideous gabble rises loud Among the builders.

sn.def: Inarticulate sounds rapidly uttered; as of fowls.

entry.def: One who gabbles; a prater.

entry.ety: It
entry.def: A name originally given by the Italians to a kind of serpentine, later to the rock called euphotide, and now generally used for a coarsely crystalline, igneous rock consisting of lamellar pyroxene (diallage) and labradorite, with sometimes chrysolite (olivine gabbro).

entry.ety: F. gabelle, LL. gabella gabulum gablum; of uncertain origin. Cf.Gavel tribute
entry.def: A rent, service, tribute, custom, tax, impost, or duty; an excise.
entry.q: He enables St. Peter to pay his gabel by the ministry of a fish.

entry.def: A collector of gabels or taxes.

entry.ety: F. See Gabel
entry.def: A tax, especially on salt.
A gabeler.
See Gabardine.

entry.ety: Gael. gabair talker + lunndair idler
entry.def: A beggar with a wallet; a licensed beggar.

entry.ety: Cf.F.gabare, Arm. kobar gobar
entry.def: A lighter, or vessel for inland navigation.

entry.ety: F., from It. gabbione a large cage, gabion, from gabbia cage, L. cavea. See Cage

sn.def: A hollow cylinder of wickerwork, like a basket without a bottom. Gabions are made of various sizes, and filled with earth in building fieldworks to shelter men from an enemy's fire.
An openwork frame, as of poles, filled with stones and sunk, to assist in forming a bar dyke, etc., as in harbor improvement.

entry.ety: F. gabionnade

sn.def: A traverse made with gabions between guns or on their flanks, protecting them from enfilading fire.
A structure of gabions sunk in lines, as a core for a sand bar in harbor improvements.

entry.ety: F. gabionnage
entry.def: The part of a fortification built of gabions.
Furnished with gabions.
See Gabionade.
A cable.

entries.entry:
Ga"ble
Bell gable. See under Bell. Gable roof a double sloping roof which forms a gable at each end. Gable wall. Same as Gable. Gable window a window in a gable.
n. OE. gable gabil, F. gable, fr. LL. gabalum front of a building, prob. of German or Scand. origin; cf. OHG. gibil, G. giebel gable, Icel. gafl, Goth. gibla pinnacle; perh. akin to Gr. � head, and E. cephalic, or to G. gabel fork, AS. geafl, E. gaffle, L. gabalus a kind of gallows Arch The vertical triangular portion of the end of a building, from the level of the cornice or eaves to the ridge of the roof. Also, a similar end when not triangular in shape, as of a gambrel roof and the like. Hence: The end wall of a building, as distinguished from the front or rear side. A decorative member having the shape of a triangular gable, such as that above a Gothic arch in a doorway.

entry.def: furnished or constructed with a gable; -- of a house or roof; as, a gabled roof. Opposite of ungabled.
A small gable, or gable-shaped canopy, formed over a tabernacle, niche, etc.

entry.ety: See Gavelock
entry.def: A false spur or gaff, fitted on the heel of a gamecock.
of or relating to Gabon or its inhabitants; as, Gabonese hills; Gabonese writers.
a native or inhabitant of Gabon.

entry.ety: Icel. gapi a rash, reckless man. Cf. Gafe
entry.def: A simpleton; a dunce; a lout.

entry.cs: Upon the gad upon the spur of the moment; hastily. Obs “All this done upon the gad!” Shak.
entry.ety: OE. gad, Icel. gaddr goad, sting; akin to Sw. gadd sting, Goth. gazds, G. gerte switch. See Yard a measure

sn.def: The point of a spear, or an arrowhead.
A pointed or wedge-shaped instrument of metal, as a steel wedge used in mining, etc.
sn.q: I will go get a leaf of brass, And with a gad of steel will write these words.

sn.def: A sharp-pointed rod; a goad.
A spike on a gauntlet; a gadling.
A wedge-shaped billet of iron or steel.
sn.q: Flemish steel . . . some in bars and some in gads.

sn.def: A rod or stick, as a fishing rod, a measuring rod, or a rod used to drive cattle with.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Gadded; p. pr. & vb. n. Gadding
entry.ety: Prob. fr. gad n., and orig. meaning to drive about
entry.def: To walk about; to rove or go about, without purpose; hence, to run wild; to be uncontrolled.
entry.q: Thegaddingvine.
Why gaddest thou about so much to change thy way?

entry.def: A gadder
The gadfly.
One who roves about idly, a rambling gossip.

cs.cd: in quarrying, a car which carries a drilling machine so arranged as to drill a line of holes.

entry.def: Going about much, needlessly or without purpose.
entry.q: Envy is a gadding passion, and walketh the streets.
The good nuns would check her gadding tongue.

entry.def: In a roving, idle manner.

entry.wordforms: Gad"dish*nes n. “Gaddishness and folly.” Abp. Leighton.
entry.def: Disposed to gad.

entry.ety: Cf. Cod the fish
entry.def: A small British fish (Motella argenteola) of the Cod family.
A pike, so called at Moray Firth; -- called also gead.
To gather.

entries.entry:
Gad"fly` ☞ The sheep gadfly Oestrus ovis) deposits its young in the nostrils of sheep, and the larvæ develop in the frontal sinuses. The common species which infests cattle (Hypoderma bovis) deposits its eggs upon or in the skin where the larvæ or bots live and produce sores called wormels. The gadflies of the horse produce the intestinal parasites called bots. See Botfly, and Bots. The true horseflies are often erroneously called gadflies, and the true gadflies are sometimes incorrectly called breeze flies.
Gadfly petrel Zoöl one of several small petrels of the genus Oestrelata.
găd"flī` n.; pl.Gadflies #.
Gad + fly
Zoöl Any dipterous insect of the genus Oestrus, and allied genera of botflies.

entry.ety: See Gael
entry.def: Of, belonging to, or designating, that division of the Celtic languages which includes the Irish, Gaelic, and Manx.
Pertaining to, or derived from, the cod (Gadus); -- applied to an acid obtained from cod-liver oil, viz., gadic acid.

entry.ety: L. Gaditanus, fr. Gades Cadiz
entry.def: Of or relating to Cadiz, in Spain.

def2.def: A native or inhabitant of Cadiz.

entry.ety: Gad, n. + -ling
entry.def: See Gad n., 4.

entry.ety: See Gad v. i.
entry.def: Gadding about.
A roving vagabond.
A gadsman.

entry.ety: NL. gadus cod + -oid: cf. F. gadoïde gadoid, Gr. � a sort of fish, F. gade
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the family of fishes (Gadidæ) which includes the cod, haddock, and hake.

entry.ety: NL. See Gadolinite
entry.def: A rare earth associated with yttria and regarded as the oxide (Gd2O3) of a metallic element, gadolinium.
Pertaining to or containing gadolinium.

entry.ety: Named after Gadolin, a Russian chemist
entry.def: A mineral of a nearly black color and vitreous luster, and consisting principally of the silicates of yttrium, cerium, and iron.

entry.ety: NL. See Gadolinite
entry.def: A rare earth metallic element of the Lanthanide series, with a characteristic spectrum, found associated with yttrium and other rare earth elements. Symbol, Gd; it has an atomic number of 64, an atomic weight of 157.25 (C=12.011), and a valence of +3.
One who uses a gad or goad in driving.

entry.ety: NL. gadus codfish
entry.def: A yellow or brown amorphous substance, of indifferent nature, found in cod-liver oil.

entry.ety: Gad to walk about + well
entry.def: A large duck (Anas strepera), valued as a game bird, found in the northern parts of Europe and America; -- called also gray duck.

entry.ety: Gr. Gai^a Gh^
entry.def: The goddess of the earth, considered as a personification of the earth. According to Hesiod she was the first-born of Chaos, and mother of Uranus, Pontus, Cronus and the Titans in ancient mythology.

entry.ety: Also Gaikwar Guicowar
Marathi gāekwār, prop., a cowherd
entry.def: The title of the ruling Prince of Baroda, in Gujarat, in Bombay, India.

entry.ety: See Gaelic
entry.def: A Celt or the Celts of the Scotch Highlands or of Ireland; now esp., a Scotch Highlander of Celtic origin.

entry.ety: Gael. Gàidhealach Gaelach, from Gàidheal Gael, a Scotch Highlander
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the Gael, esp. to the Celtic Highlanders of Scotland; as, the Gaelic language.

entry.ety: Gael. Gaelig Gàilig
entry.def: The language of the Gaels, esp. of the Highlanders of Scotland. It is a branch of the Celtic.

entry.ety: OE. gaffe, F. gaffe an iron hook with which seamen pull great fishes into their ships; cf. Ir. gaf gafa hook; perh. akin to G. gabel fork, Skr. gabhasti. Cf. Gaffle Gable

sn.def: A barbed spear or a hook with a handle, used by fishermen in securing heavy fish.
The spar upon which the upper edge of a fore-and-aft sail is extended.
Same as Gaffle, 1.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Gaffed; p. pr. & vb. n. Gaffing
entry.def: To strike with a gaff or barbed spear; to secure by means of a gaff; as, to gaff a salmon.
A socially awkward or tactless act.

entry.note: ☞ Gaffer was originally a respectful title, now degenerated into a term of familiarity or contempt when addressed to an aged man in humble life.
entry.ety: Possibly contr. fr. godfather; but prob. fr. gramfer for grandfather. Cf. Gammer

sn.def: An old fellow; an aged rustic.
sn.q: Go to each gaffer and each goody.

sn.def: A foreman or overseer of a gang of laborers.

entry.ety: Cf. AS. geafl fork, LG., D., Sw., & Dan. gaffel, G. gabel, W. gafl, Ir. & Gael. gabhal. Cf. Gaff

sn.def: An artificial spur or gaff for gamecocks.
A lever to bend crossbows.

entry.def: A small triangular sail having its foot extended upon the gaff and its luff upon the topmast.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Gagged; p. pr. & vb. n. Gagging
entry.ety: Prob. fr. W. cegio to choke or strangle, fr. ceg mouth, opening, entrance

sn.def: To stop the mouth of, by thrusting sometimes in, so as to hinder speaking; hence, to silence by authority or by violence; not to allow freedom of speech to.
sn.q: The time was not yet come when eloquence was to be gagged, and reason to be hood winked.

sn.def: To pry or hold open by means of a gag.
sn.q: Mouths gagged to such a wideness.

sn.def: To cause to heave with nausea.
To heave with nausea; to retch.
To introduce gags or interpolations. See Gag n., 3.

cs.cd: a rein for drawing the bit upward in the horse's mouth.
a loop on the throat latch guiding the gag rein.

sn.def: Something thrust into the mouth or throat to hinder speaking.
A mouthful that makes one retch; a choking bit; as, a gag of mutton fat.
A speech or phrase interpolated offhand by an actor on the stage in his part as written, usually consisting of some seasonable or local allusion.
mentally or physically infirm with age.
marked by foolish or unreasoning fondness; as, gaga over his girlfriend.
sn.syn: crazy about, dotty, enamored, infatuated, in love, smitten, soft on(predicate), taken with(predicate).

entry.ety: L. gagates. See Jet a black mineral
entry.def: Agate.

entry.ety: F. gage, LL. gadium wadium; of German origin; cf. Goth. wadi, OHG. wetti weti, akin to E. wed. See Wed, and cf. Wage n.

sn.def: A pledge or pawn; something laid down or given as a security for the performance of some act by the person depositing it, and forfeited by nonperformance; security.
sn.q: Nor without gages to the needy lend.

sn.def: A glove, cap, or the like, cast on the ground as a challenge to combat, and to be taken up by the accepter of the challenge; a challenge; a defiance.
sn.q: There I throw mygage.

entry.ety: So called because an English family named Gage imported the greengage from France, in the last century
entry.def: A variety of plum; as, the greengage; also, the blue gage, frost gage, golden gage, etc., having more or less likeness to the greengage. See Greengage.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Gaged gājd; p. pr & vb. n. Gaging gā"jĭng
entry.ety: Cf. F. gager. See Gage n., a pledge

sn.def: To give or deposit as a pledge or security for some act; to wage or wager; to pawn or pledge.
sn.q: A moiety competent Was gaged by our king.

sn.def: To bind by pledge, or security; to engage.
sn.q: Great debts Wherein my time, sometimes too prodigal, Hath left me gaged.

entry.def: A measure or standard. See Gauge n.
To measure. See Gauge v. t.
entry.q: You shall not gage meBy what we do to-night.

entry.def: A measurer. See Gauger.

sn.def: One who gags.
A piece of iron imbedded in the sand of a mold to keep the sand in place.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Gaggled; p. pr. & vb. n. Gaggling
entry.ety: Of imitative origin; cf. D. gaggelen gagelen, G. gackeln gackern, MHG. gāgen, E. giggle cackle
entry.def: To make a noise like a goose; to cackle.

entry.ety: Cf. Gaggle v. i.

sn.def: A flock of wild geese, especially when on the ground.
A gathering of people, especially a noisy one.
Any clustered group of related objects.

entries.entry: Gag law. Parliamentary Law A law or ruling prohibiting proper or free debate, as in closure. Colloq. or Cant
gag"tooth` găg"t�th` n.; pl.Gagteeth găg"tēth`. A projecting tooth. Obs

entry.def: Having gagteeth.

entry.ety: Named after Gahn , a Swedish chemist
entry.def: Zinc spinel; automolite.

entry.ety: Gr. gai^a earth
entry.def: Goddess of the earth; same as Gaea.

entry.ety: Gr. gai^a earth
entry.def: Pertaining to hypogeic acid; -- applied to an acid obtained from hypogeic acid.
Same as Gayety.
A jailer.

entry.ety: F. See Galliard
entry.def: Gay; brisk; merry; galliard.

entry.ety: See Galliard a dance
entry.def: A lively French and Italian dance.

entry.ety: From Gay
entry.def: Merrily; showily. See gaily.

entry.ety: Cf. W. gan a mortise
entry.def: A square or beveled notch cut out of a girder, binding joist, or other timber which supports a floor beam, so as to receive the end of the floor beam.

entry.ety: OE. gein gain, good, near, quick; cf. Icel. gegn ready, serviceable, and gegn, adv., against, opposite. Cf. Ahain
entry.def: Convenient; suitable; direct; near; handy; dexterous; easy; profitable; cheap; respectable.

entry.ety: OE. gain gein gaȝhen, gain, advantage, Icel. gagn; akin to Sw. gagn, Dan. gavn, cf. Goth. gageigan to gain. The word was prob. influenced by F. gain gain, OF. gaain. Cf. Gain v. t.

sn.def: That which is gained, obtained, or acquired, as increase, profit, advantage, or benefit; -- opposed to loss.
sn.q: But what things were gain to me, those I counted loss for Christ.
Godliness with contentment is great gain.
Every one shall share in the gains.

sn.def: The obtaining or amassing of profit or valuable possessions; acquisition; accumulation.
sn.q: The lust ofgain.

cs.cd: the calendar day gained in sailing eastward around the earth.
to make progress; to advance in any undertaking; to prevail; to acquire strength or extent.
to draw to one's party or interest; to win over.
to reach the windward side of another ship.

entry.usage: See Obtain.To Gain Win. Gain implies only that we get something by exertion; win, that we do it in competition with others. A person gains knowledge, or gains a prize, simply by striving for it; he wins a victory, or wins a prize, by taking it in a struggle with others.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Gained gānd; p. pr. & vb. n. Gaining
entry.ety: From gain n. but. prob. influenced by F. gagner to earn, gain, OF. gaaignier to cultivate, OHG. weidinōn weidinen to pasture, hunt, fr. weida pasturage, G. weide, akin to Icel. veiðr hunting, AS. wāðu, cf. L. venari to hunt, E. venison. See Gain n., profit

sn.def: To get, as profit or advantage; to obtain or acquire by effort or labor; as, to gain a good living.
sn.q: What is a man profited, if he shall gain the whole world, and lose his own soul?
To gain dominion, or to keep it gained.
For fame with toil we gain, but lose with ease.

sn.def: To come off winner or victor in; to be successful in; to obtain by competition; as, to gain a battle; to gain a case at law; to gain a prize.
To draw into any interest or party; to win to one's side; to conciliate.
sn.q: If he shall hear thee, thou hast gained thy brother.
To gratify the queen, and gained the court.

sn.def: To reach; to attain to; to arrive at; as, to gain the top of a mountain; to gain a good harbor.
sn.q: Forded Usk and gained the wood.

sn.def: To get, incur, or receive, as loss, harm, or damage.
sn.q: Ye should . . . not have loosed from Crete, and to have gained this harm and loss.
sn.syn: To obtain; acquire; get; procure; win; earn; attain; achieve.

entry.cs:
Gaining twist in rifled firearms, a twist of the grooves, which increases regularly from the breech to the muzzle.
To gain onorTo gain upon . To encroach on; as, the ocean gains on the land. To obtain influence with. To win ground upon; to move faster than, as in a race or contest. To get the better of; to have the advantage of. The English have not only gained upon the Venetians in the Levant, but have their cloth in Venice itself. Addison.
entry.def: To have or receive advantage or profit; to acquire gain; to grow rich; to advance in interest, health, or happiness; to make progress; as, the sick man gains daily.
entry.q: Thou hast greedily gained of thy neighbors by extortion.
My good behavior had so far gained on the emperor, that I began to conceive hopes of liberty.

entry.ety: CF. F. gagnable. See Gain v. t.
entry.def: Capable of being obtained or reached.

entry.ety: OF. gaignage pasturage, crop, F. gaignage pasturage. See Gain v. t.
entry.def: The horses, oxen, plows, wains or wagons and implements for carrying on tillage.
The profit made by tillage; also, the land itself.
One who gains.
Profitable; advantageous; lucrative.
entry.q: Againfulspeculation.

entry.ety: See Again, and Give
entry.def: A misgiving.
Not producing gain; unprofitable.

entry.ety: See Gain a.
entry.def: Handily; readily; dexterously; advantageously.

entry.ety: F. gagner to gain + pain bread
entry.def: Bread-gainer; -- a term applied in the Middle Ages to the sword of a hired soldier.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Gainsaid ? or ?; p. pr. & vb. n. Gainsaying
entry.ety: OE. geinseien ageinseien. See Again, and Say to utter
entry.def: To contradict; to deny; to controvert; to dispute; to forbid.
entry.q: I will give you a mouth and wisdom which all your adversaries shall not be able to gainsay nor resist.
The just gods gainsay That any drop thou borrow'dst from thy mother, My sacred aunt, should by my mortal sword Be drained.

entry.def: One who gainsays, contradicts, or denies.
entry.q: To convince thegainsayers.

entries.entry: Gains"borough hat. A woman's broad-brimmed hat of a form thought to resemble those shown in portraits by Thomas Gainsborough , the English artist (1727-88).

sn.def: Gainful.
Prepossessing; well-favored.

entry.def: A contraction of Against.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Gainstood; p. pr. & vb. n. gainstanding
entry.ety: See Again, and Stand
entry.def: To withstand; to resist.
entry.q: Durst . . . gainstand the force of so many enraged desires.

entry.ety: See Again, and Strive
entry.def: To strive or struggle against; to withstand.
See Garefowl.
Same as Garish Garishly Garishness.

entry.ety: See Gate a way

sn.def: A going; a walk; a march; a way.
sn.q: Good gentleman, go your gait, and let poor folks pass.

sn.def: Manner of walking or stepping; bearing or carriage while moving.
sn.q: 'T is Cinna; I do know him by his gait.

entry.def: Having (such) a gait; -- used in composition; as, slow-gaited; heavy-gaited.

entry.ety: F. guêtre, cf. Armor. gweltren; or perh. of German origin, and akin to E. wear, v

sn.def: A covering of cloth or leather for the ankle and instep, or for the whole leg from the knee to the instep, fitting down upon the shoe.
A kind of shoe, consisting of cloth, and covering the ankle.

entry.def: To dress with gaiters.

entry.ety: OE. Cf. Gatten tree
entry.def: The dogwood tree.

cs.cd: a day of mirth and festivity; a holiday.

entry.ety: F. gala show, pomp, fr. It. gala finery, gala; of German origin. See Gallant
entry.def: Pomp, show, or festivity.

entry.ety: Gr. �, �, milk + � to lead
entry.def: An agent exciting secretion of milk.

cs.cd: the great circle of the heavens, to which the course of the galaxy most nearly conforms.
the poles of the galactic circle.

entry.ety: Gr. � milky, fr. �, �, milk. See Galaxy, and cf. Lactic

sn.def: Of or pertaining to milk; got from milk; as, galactic acid.
Of or pertaining to the galaxy or Milky Way.

entry.ety: Gr. �, �, milk. Cf. Lactin
entry.def: An amorphous, gelatinous substance containing nitrogen, found in milk and other animal fluids. It resembles peptone, and is variously regarded as a coagulating or emulsifying agent.
A white waxy substance found in the sap of the South American cow tree (Galactodendron).
An amorphous, gummy carbohydrate resembling gelose, found in the seeds of leguminous plants, and yielding on decomposition several sugars, including galactose.

entry.ety: Gr. �, � + E. densimeter
entry.def: Same as Galactometer.

entry.ety: Gr. �, �, milk + -meter: cf. F. galactomètre. Cf. Lactometer
entry.def: An instrument for ascertaining the quality of milk (i.e., its richness in cream) by determining its specific gravity; a lactometer.

entry.ety: Gr. �, �, milk + � to eat: cf. � to live on milk
entry.def: One who eats, or subsists on, milk.

entry.ety: Gr. �: cf. F. galactophade
entry.def: Feeding on milk.

entry.ety: Gr. �; �, �, milk + fe`rein to bear: cf. F. galactophore. Cf. Lactiferous
entry.def: Milk-carrying; lactiferous; -- applied to the ducts of mammary glands.

entry.ety: Gr. �, �, milk + � capable of making; fr. � to make
entry.def: Increasing the flow of milk; milk-producing.

A white, crystalline sugar, C6H12O6, isomeric with dextrose, obtained by the decomposition of milk sugar, and also from certain gums. When oxidized it forms mucic acid. Called also lactosethough it is not lactose proper).
See Galoche.

entries.entry: Ga*la"go ☞ The grand galago Galago crassicaudata) is about the size of a cat; the mouse galago G. murinus)is about the size of a mouse. n.; pl.Galagos #. Native name Zoöl A genus of African lemurs, including numerous species.

entry.ety: OE. galingale, OF. galingal garingal, F. galangacf. Sp. galanga), prob. fr. Ar. khalanjān.
entry.def: The pungent aromatic rhizome or tuber of certain East Indian or Chinese species of Alpinia Alpinia Galanga and Alpinia officinarum) and of the Kæmpferia Galanga), -- all of the Ginger family.

entry.ety: After Galatea, a British man-of-war, the material being used for children's sailor suits
entry.def: A kind of striped cotton fabric, usually of superior quality and striped with blue or red on white.

entry.ety: F. galantine
entry.def: A dish of veal, chickens, or other white meat, freed from bones, tied up, boiled, and served cold.
The West Indian Sciadophyllum Brownei, a tree with very large digitate leaves.
Of or pertaining to Galatia or its inhabitants. -- A native or inhabitant of Galatia, in Asia Minor; a descendant of the Gauls who settled in Asia Minor.

entries.entry:
Gal"ax*y n.; pl.Galaxies #. F. galaxie, L. galaxias, fr. Gr. � (sc. � circle), fr. �, �, milk; akin to L. lac. Cf. Lacteal
Astron
The Milky Way, that luminous tract, or belt, which is seen at night stretching across the heavens, and which is composed of innumerable stars, so distant and blended as to be distinguishable only with the telescope.
A very large collection of stars comparable in size to the Milky Way system, held together by gravitational force and separated from other such star systems by large distances of mostly empty space. Galaxies vary widely in shape and size, the most common nearby galaxies being over 70,000 light years in diameter and separated from each other by even larger distances. The number of stars in one galaxy varies, and may extend into the hundreds of billions.
A splendid or impressive assemblage of persons or things; as, a galaxy of movie stars.

entry.ety: L. galbanum, Gr. �, prob. from Heb. klekb'n�h: cf. F. galbanum
entry.def: A gum resin exuding from the stems of certain Asiatic umbelliferous plants, mostly species of Ferula. The Bubon Galbanum of South Africa furnishes an inferior kind of galbanum. It has an acrid, bitter taste, a strong, unpleasant smell, and is used for medical purposes, also in the arts, as in the manufacture of varnish.

entry.ety: F.; OF. garbe, fr. It. garbo grace, gracefulness. See Garb dress
entry.def: The general outward form of any solid object, as of a column or a vase.
A natural family of tropical American birds comprising the jacamars.

entry.note: ☞ Gales have a velocity of from about eighteen (“moderate”) to about eighty (“very heavy”) miles an our.

cs.cd: one in which a ship may carry her topgallant sails.

entry.ety: Prob. of Scand. origin; cf. Dan. gal furious, Icel. galinn, cf. Icel. gala to sing, AS. galan to sing, Icel. galdr song, witchcraft, AS. galdor charm, sorcery, E. nightingale; also, Icel. gjōla gust of wind, gola breeze. Cf. Yell

sn.def: A strong current of air; a wind between a stiff breeze and a hurricane. The most violent gales are called tempests.
A moderate current of air; a breeze.
sn.q: A little gale will soon disperse that cloud.
And winds of gentlest gale Arabian odors fanned From their soft wings.

sn.def: A state of excitement, passion, or hilarity.
sn.q: The ladies, laughing heartily, were fast getting into what, in New England, is sometimes called a gale.

entry.def: To sale, or sail fast.

entry.ety: OE. gal. See Gale wind
entry.def: A song or story.

entry.ety: AS. galan. See 1st Gale
entry.def: To sing.
entry.q: Can he cry andgale.

entry.ety: AS. gagel, akin to D. gagel
entry.def: A plant of the genus Myrica, growing in wet places, and strongly resembling the bayberry. The sweet gale (Myrica Gale) is found both in Europe and in America.

cs.cd: the day on which rent or interest is due.

entry.ety: Cf. Gabel
entry.def: The payment of a rent or annuity.

entry.ety: L., a helmet

sn.def: The upper lip or helmet-shaped part of a labiate flower.
A kind of bandage for the head.
Headache extending all over the head.
A genus of fossil echini, having a vaulted, helmet-shaped shell.
The anterior, outer process of the second joint of the maxillae in certain insects.

entry.def: See Galleass.

entry.ety: L. galeatus, p. p. of galeare helmet

sn.def: Wearing a helmet; protected by a helmet; covered, as with a helmet.
Helmeted; having a helmetlike part, as a crest, a flower, etc.; helmet-shaped.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Galeus, name of one genus, fr. Gr. � a kind of shark
entry.def: That division of elasmobranch fishes which includes the sharks.

entry.cs: False galena. See Blende.
entry.ety: L. galena lead ore, dross that remains after melting lead: cf. F. galène sulphide of lead ore, antidote to poison, stillness of the sea, calm, tranquility

sn.def: A remedy or antidote for poison; theriaca.
Lead sulphide; the principal ore of lead. It is of a bluish gray color and metallic luster, and is cubic in crystallization and cleavage.

entry.def: Pertaining to, or containing, galena.

cs.cd: that branch of pharmacy which relates to the preparation of medicines by infusion, decoction, etc., as distinguished from those which are chemically prepared.

entry.ety: From Galen, the physician
entry.def: Relating to Galen or to his principles and method of treating diseases.
The doctrines of Galen.
A follower of Galen.
Galena; lead ore.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. gale`h a weasel + pi`qhkos an ape
entry.def: A genus of flying Insectivora, formerly called flying lemurs. See Colugo.

entry.ety: F. gallery
entry.def: A group of people with some common characteristic, especially a coterie of undesirable people.

entry.ety: L. galericulum, dim. of galerum a hat or cap, fr. galea helmet
entry.def: Covered as with a hat or cap.

entry.ety: L. galerum a hat, cap: cf. F. galérite
entry.def: A cretaceous fossil sea urchin of the genus Galerites.

entry.ety: Cf. Sp. Galiciano Gallego, fr. L. Gallaecus Gallaicus, fr. Gallaeci a people in Western Spain
entry.def: Of or pertaining to Galicia, in Spain, or to Galicia, the kingdom of Austrian Poland.

def2.def: A native of Galicia in Spain; -- called also Gallegan.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to Galileo; as, the Galilean telescope. See Telescope.

entry.ety: L. Galilaeus, fr. Galilaea Galilee, Gr. �: cf. F. galiléen
entry.def: Of or relating to Galilee.

sn.def: A native or inhabitant of Galilee, the northern province of Palestine under the Romans.
One of the party among the Jews, who opposed the payment of tribute to the Romans; -- called also Gaulonite.
A Christian in general; -- used as a term of reproach by Mohammedans and Pagans.

entry.ety: Supposed to have been so termed in allusion to the scriptural “Galilee of the Gentiles.” cf. OF. galilée
entry.def: A porch or waiting room, usually at the west end of an abbey church, where the monks collected on returning from processions, where bodies were laid previous to interment, and where women were allowed to see the monks to whom they were related, or to hear divine service. Also, frequently applied to the porch of a church, as at Ely and Durham cathedrals.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: Nonsense; gibberish; confused and unmeaning talk; confused mixture.
entry.q: Her dress, like her talk, is a galimatias of several countries.

entry.ety: See Galangal
entry.def: A plant of the Sedge family (Cyperus longus) having aromatic roots; also, any plant of the same genus.
entry.q: Meadow, set with slender galingale.

entry.ety: OE. galiote, F. galiote. See Galley
entry.def: A small galley, formerly used in the Mediterranean, built mainly for speed. It was moved both by sails and oars, having one mast, and sixteen or twenty seats for rowers.
A strong, light-draft, Dutch merchant vessel, carrying a mainmast and a mizzenmast, and a large gaff mainsail.

entry.ety: F. galipot; cf. OF. garipot the wild pine or pitch tree
entry.def: An impure resin of turpentine, hardened on the outside of pine trees by the spontaneous evaporation of its essential oil. When purified, it is called yellow pitch white pitch, or Burgundy pitch.

cs.cd: the membranous sac, in which the bile, or gall, is stored up, as secreted by the liver; the cholecystis. See Illust. of Digestive apparatus.
a duct which conveys bile, as the cystic duct, or the hepatic duct.
a remitting bilious fever in the Netherlands.
an herbaceous composite plant with variously lobed and cleft leaves, usually the Prenanthes serpentaria.

entry.ety: OE. galle gal, AS. gealla; akin to D. gal, OS. & OHG. galla, Icel. gall, SW. galla, Dan. galde, L. fel, Gr. �, and prob. to E. yellow. √49. See Yellow, and cf. Choler

sn.def: The bitter, alkaline, viscid fluid found in the gall bladder, beneath the liver. It consists of the secretion of the liver, or bile, mixed with that of the mucous membrane of the gall bladder.
The gall bladder.
Anything extremely bitter; bitterness; rancor.
sn.q: He hath . . . compassed me with gall and travail.
Comedy diverted without gall.

sn.def: Impudence; brazen assurance.

entry.note: ☞ The galls, or gallnuts, of commerce are produced by insects of the genus Cynips, chiefly on an oak (Quercus infectoria syn. Quercus Lusitanica) of Western Asia and Southern Europe. They contain much tannin, and are used in the manufacture of that article and for making ink and a black dye, as well as in medicine.
entry.cs: Gall insect Zoöl any insect that produces galls. Gall midge Zoöl any small dipterous insect that produces galls. Gall oak the oak (Quercus infectoria) which yields the galls of commerce. Gall of glass the neutral salt skimmed off from the surface of melted crown glass;- called also glass gall and sandiver. Ure. Gall wasp. Zoöl See Gallfly.
entry.ety: F. galle, noix de galle, fr. L. galla
entry.def: An excrescence of any form produced on any part of a plant by insects or their larvae. They are most commonly caused by small Hymenoptera and Diptera which puncture the bark and lay their eggs in the wounds. The larvae live within the galls. Some galls are due to aphids, mites, etc. See Gallnut.
To impregnate with a decoction of gallnuts.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Galled g�ld; p. pr. & vb. n. Galling
entry.ety: OE. gallen; cf. F. galer to scratch, rub, gale scurf, scab, G. galle a disease in horses' feet, an excrescence under the tongue of horses; of uncertain origin. Cf. Gall gallnut

sn.def: To fret and wear away by friction; to hurt or break the skin of by rubbing; to chafe; to injure the surface of by attrition; as, a saddle galls the back of a horse; to gall a mast or a cable.
sn.q: I am loth to gall a new-healed wound.

sn.def: To fret; to vex; as, to be galled by sarcasm.
sn.q: They that are most galled with my folly, They most must laugh.

sn.def: To injure; to harass; to annoy; as, the troops were galled by the shot of the enemy.
sn.q: In our wars against the French of old, we used to gall them with our longbows, at a greater distance than they could shoot their arrows.

entry.def: To scoff; to jeer.
A wound in the skin made by rubbing.

entry.usage: Courageous is generic, denoting an inward spirit which rises above fear; brave is more outward, marking a spirit which braves or defies danger; gallant rises still higher, denoting bravery on extraordinary occasions in a spirit of adventure. A courageous man is ready for battle; a brave man courts it; a gallant man dashes into the midst of the conflict.
entry.ety: F. gallant, prop. p. pr. of OF. galer to rejoice, akin to OF. gale amusement, It. gala ornament; of German origin; cf. OHG. geil merry, luxuriant, wanton, G. geil lascivious, akin to AS. gāl wanton, wicked, OS. gēl merry, Goth. gailjan to make to rejoice, or perh. akin to E. weal. See Gala Galloon

sn.def: Showy; splendid; magnificent; gay; well-dressed.
sn.q: The town is built in a very gallant place.
Our royal, good and gallant ship.

sn.def: Noble in bearing or spirit; brave; high-spirited; courageous; heroic; magnanimous; as, a gallant youth; a gallant officer.
sn.q: That gallant spirit hath aspired the clouds.
The gay, the wise, the gallant, and the grave.

entry.def: Polite and attentive to ladies; courteous to women; chivalrous.

entry.note: ☞ In the first sense it is by some orthoëpists (as in Shakespeare) accented on the first syllable.

sn.def: A man of mettle or spirit; a gay, fashionable man; a young blood.
One fond of paying attention to ladies.
One who wooes; a lover; a suitor; in a bad sense, a seducer.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Gallanted; p. pr. & vb. n. Gallanting

sn.def: To attend or wait on, as a lady; as, to gallant ladies to the play.
To handle with grace or in a modish manner; as, to gallant a fan.

entry.def: In a polite or courtly manner; like a gallant or wooer.
In a gallant manner.
The quality of being gallant.

entries.entry:
Gal"lant*ry n.; pl.Gallantries #. F. galanterie
Splendor of appearance; ostentatious finery. Archaic Guess the gallantry of our church by this . . . when the desk whereon the priest read was inlaid with plates of silver.
Bravery; intrepidity; as, the troops behaved with great gallantry .
Civility or polite attention to ladies; in a bad sense, attention or courtesy designed to win criminal favors from a female; freedom of principle or practice with respect to female virtue; intrigue.
Gallant persons, collectively. R Helenus, Antenor, and all the gallantry of Troy. See Courage, and Heroism.

entry.ety: Cf. F. gallate. See Gall gallnut
entry.def: A salt of gallic acid.

entry.ety: From L. gallus a cock
entry.def: The tread, treadle, or chalasa of an egg.

entry.note: ☞ “The galleasses . . . were a third larger than the ordinary galley, and rowed each by three hundred galley slaves. They consisted of an enormous towering structure at the stern, a castellated structure almost equally massive in front, with seats for the rowers amidships.”
entry.ety: F. galéasse galéace; cf. It. galeazza, Sp. galeaza; LL. galea a galley. See Galley
entry.def: A large galley, having some features of the galleon, as broadside guns; esp., such a vessel used by the southern nations of Europe in the 16th and 17th centuries. See Galleon, and Galley.

entry.mhw: Gal*le"gan găl*lē"g�n Gal*le"go găl*lē"g� or gȧ*lyā"g�,
entry.ety: Sp. Gallego
entry.def: A native or inhabitant of Galicia, in Spain; a Galician.

entry.ety: Pyrogallol + phthaleïn
entry.def: A red crystalline dyestuff, obtained by heating together pyrogallic and phthalic acids.

entry.ety: Sp. galeon, cf. F. galion; fr. LL. galeo galio. See Galley
entry.def: A sailing vessel of the 15th and following centuries, often having three or four decks, and used for war or commerce. The term is often rather indiscriminately applied to any large sailing vessel.
entry.q: The galleons . . . were huge, round-stemmed, clumsy vessels, with bulwarks three or four feet thick, and built up at stem and stern, like castles.

entry.def: See Galiot.

entries.entry:
Gal"ler*y
Whispering gallery. See under Whispering.
n.; pl.Galleries #. F. galerie, It. galleria, fr. LL. galeria gallery, perh. orig., a festal hall, banquetting hall; cf. OF. galerie a rejoicing, fr. galer to rejoice. Cf. Gallant a.
A long and narrow corridor, or place for walking; a connecting passageway, as between one room and another; also, a long hole or passage excavated by a boring or burrowing animal.
A room for the exhibition of works of art; as, a picture gallery ; hence, also, a large or important collection of paintings, sculptures, etc.
A long and narrow platform attached to one or more sides of public hall or the interior of a church, and supported by brackets or columns; -- sometimes intended to be occupied by musicians or spectators, sometimes designed merely to increase the capacity of the hall.
Naut A frame, like a balcony, projecting from the stern or quarter of a ship, and hence called stern gallery or quarter gallery, -- seldom found in vessels built since 1850.
Fort Any communication which is covered overhead as well as at the sides. When prepared for defense, it is a defensive gallery.
Mining A working drift or level.

entry.ety: OE. gallytile. Cf. Gallipot
entry.def: A little tile of glazed earthenware.
entry.q: The substance ofgalletyle.

entries.entry:
Gal"ley ☞ The typical galley of the Mediterranean was from one hundred to two hundred feet long, often having twenty oars on each side. It had two or three masts rigged with lateen sails, carried guns at prow and stern, and a complement of one thousand to twelve hundred men, and was very efficient in mediaeval warfare. Galleons, galliots, galleasses, half galleys, and quarter galleys were all modifications of this type.
Galley slave a person condemned, often as a punishment for crime, to work at the oar on board a galley. “To toil like a galley slave.” Macaulay. Galley slice Print a sliding false bottom to a large galley. Knight.
n.; pl.Galleys #. OE. gale galeiecf. OF. galie galée, LL. galea, LGr. �; of unknown origin
Naut A vessel propelled by oars, whether having masts and sails or not; as: A large vessel for war and national purposes; -- common in the Middle Ages, and down to the 17th century.
A name given by analogy to the Greek, Roman, and other ancient vessels propelled by oars.
A light, open boat used on the Thames by customhouse officers, press gangs, and also for pleasure.
One of the small boats carried by a man-of-war.
The cookroom or kitchen and cooking apparatus of a vessel; -- sometimes on merchant vessels called the caboose.
Chem An oblong oven or muffle with a battery of retorts; a gallery furnace.
F. galée; the same word as E. galley a vessel Print
An oblong tray of wood or brass, with upright sides, for holding type which has been set, or is to be made up, etc.
A proof sheet taken from type while on a galley; a galley proof.

entry.ety: Etymol. uncertain
entry.def: The European green woodpecker, called also the yaffle; also, the spotted woodpecker.

entry.ety: Prob. so called because the numerous legs along the sides move rhythmically like the oars of a galley
entry.def: A chilognath myriapod of the genus Iulus, and allied genera, having numerous short legs along the sides; a milliped or “thousand legs.” See Chilognatha.

entries.entry: Gall"fly` n.; pl.Gallflies. Zoöl An insect that deposits its eggs in plants, and occasions galls, esp. any small hymenopteran of the genus Cynips and allied genera. See Illust. of Gall.

entry.ety: L. galliambus a song used by the priests of Cybele; Gallusa name applied to these priests) + iambus
entry.def: Consisting of two iambic dimeters catalectic, the last of which lacks the final syllable; -- said of a kind of verse.

entry.ety: See Gallic
entry.def: Gallic; French.

entry.ety: OE., fr. F. gaillard, perh. of Celtic origin; cf. Ir. & Gael. galach valiant, or AS. gagol geagl, wanton, lascivious
entry.def: Gay; brisk; active.
A brisk, gay man.
entry.q: Selden is a galliard by himself.

entry.ety: F. gaillarde, cf. Sp. gallarda. See Galliard a.
entry.def: A gay, lively dance. Cf. Gailliarde.
entry.q: Never a hall such a galliard did grace.

entry.ety: F. gaillardise. See Galliard a.
entry.def: Excessive gayety; merriment.
entry.q: The mirth and galliardise of company.

entry.def: Gayety.
Same as Galleass.

entry.ety: From Gallium
entry.def: Pertaining to, or containing, gallium.

cs.cd: an organic acid, very widely distributed in the vegetable kingdom, being found in the free state in galls, tea, etc., and produced artificially. It is a white, crystalline substance, C6H2(HO)3.CO2H, with an astringent taste, and is a strong reducing agent, as employed in photography. It is usually prepared from tannin, and both give a dark color with iron salts, forming tannate and gallate of iron, which are the essential ingredients of common black ink.

entry.ety: From Gall the excrescence
entry.def: Pertaining to, or derived from, galls, nutgalls, and the like.

entry.ety: L. Gallicus belonging to the Gauls, fr. Galli the Gauls, Gallia Gaul, now France: cf. F. gallique
entry.def: Pertaining to Gaul or France; Gallican.

entry.ety: L. Gallicanus: cf. F. gallican
entry.def: Of or pertaining to Gaul or France; Gallic; French; as, the Gallican church or clergy.
An adherent to, and supporter of, Gallicanism.

The principles, tendencies, or action of those, within the Roman Catholic Church in France, who (esp. in 1682) sought to restrict the papal authority in that country and increase the power of the national church.

entry.ety: F. gallicisme
entry.def: A mode of speech peculiar to the French; a French idiom; also, in general, a French mode or custom.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Gallicized; p. pr. & vb. n. Gallicizing
entry.def: To conform to the French mode or idiom.
Worried; flurried; frightened.
Like the Gallinae (or Galliformes) in structure.

entry.ety: Prob. corrupted fr. It. Grechesco Grecian, a name which seems to have been given in Venice, and to have been afterwards confused with Gascony, as if they came from Gascony
entry.def: Loose hose or breeches; leather leg quards. The word is used loosely and often in a jocose sense.
Senseless talk. Obs. or R See Galimatias.

entries.entry:
Gal`li*mau"fry n.; pl.Gallimaufries #. F. galimafrée a sort of ragout or mixed hash of different meats
A hash of various kinds of meats, a ragout. Delighting in hodge-podge, gallimaufries, forced meat.
Any absurd medley; a hotchpotch. The Mahometan religion, which, being a gallimaufry made up of many, partakes much of the Jewish.

entry.def: A substance obtained by the reduction of galleïn.

entry.ety: NL. See Gallinaceous
entry.def: Same as Gallinae.
One of the Gallinae or gallinaceous birds.

entry.ety: L. gallinaceus, fr. gallina hen, fr. gallus cock
entry.def: Resembling the domestic fowls and pheasants; of or pertaining to the Gallinae.

entries.entry: ‖Gal*li"nae n.; pl. NL., fr. L. gallina a hen, gallus a cock Zoöl An order of birds, including the common domestic fowls, pheasants, grouse, quails, and allied forms; -- sometimes called Rasores .

entry.def: A genus of birds consisting of certain of the snipes.
Fitted to gall or chafe; vexing; harassing; irritating.
A large mosquito.

entry.note: ☞ The purple gallinule of Southern Europe and Asia was formerly believed to be able to detect and report adultery, and for that reason, chiefly, it was commonly domesticated by the ancients.
entry.ety: L. gallinula chicken, dim. of gallina hen: cf. F. gallinule
entry.def: One of several wading birds, having long, webless toes, and a frontal shield, belonging to the family Rallidae. They are remarkable for running rapidly over marshes and on floating plants. The purple gallinule of America is Ionornis Martinica, that of the Old World is Porphyrio porphyrio. The common European gallinule (Gallinula chloropus) is also called moor hen water hen water rail moor coot night bird, and erroneously dabchick. Closely related to it is the Florida gallinule (Gallinula galeata).
See Galiot.

entries.entry: Gal*lip"o*li oil`. An inferior kind of olive oil, brought from Gallipoli, in Italy.

entry.ety: Prob. fr. OD. gleypot, the first part of which is possibly akin to E. glad. See Glad, and Pot
entry.def: A glazed earthen pot or vessel, used by druggists and apothecaries for containing medicines, etc.

entry.ety: NL.; perh. fr. L. Gallia France
entry.def: A rare metallic element, found combined in certain zinc ores. It is white, hard, and malleable, resembling aluminium, and remarkable for its low melting point (86° F., 30° C.). Symbol, Ga; at. wt., 69.9. Gallium is chiefly trivalent, resembling aluminium and indium. It was predicted with most of its properties, under the name eka-aluminium, by the Russian chemist Mendelyeev on the basis of the periodic law. This prediction was verified in its discovery (in 1875) by the French chemist Lecoq de Boisbaudran by its characteristic spectrum (two violet lines), in an examination of a zinc blende from the Pyrenees.

entry.ety: From Gallant
entry.def: To play the beau; to wait upon the ladies; also, to roam about for pleasure without any definite plan.

entry.ety: Prob. fr. Pg. galeota; cf. E. galiot galley
entry.def: A small armed vessel, with sails and oars, -- used on the Malabar coast.

entry.ety: Etymol. uncertain
entry.def: A West Indian lizard (Celestus occiduus), about a foot long, imagined by the natives to be venomous.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Gallized; p. pr. & vb. n. Gallizing
entry.ety: After Dr. L. Gall , a French chemist, who invented the process
entry.def: In wine making, to add water and sugar to (unfermented grape juice) so as to increase the quantity of wine produced.
A round gall produced on the leaves and shoots of various species of the oak tree. See Gall, and Nutgall.

A common perennial herb (Nabalus serpentarius) widely distributed in southern and eastern U. S., having drooping clusters of pinkish flowers and thick basal leaves suggesting a lion's foot in shape; sometimes placed in the genus Prenanthes.
entry.syn: lion's foot, gall of the earth, Nabalus serpentarius Prenanthes serpentaria.

entry.ety: L. Galli Gauls + mania madness
entry.def: An excessive admiration of what is French.

entry.note: ☞ The standart gallon of the Unites States contains 231 cubic inches, or 8.3389 pounds avoirdupois of distilled water at its maximum density, and with the barometer at 30 inches. This is almost exactly equivalent to a cylinder of seven inches in diameter and six inches in height, and is the same as the old English wine gallon. The beer gallon, now little used in the United States, contains 282 cubic inches. The English imperial gallon contains 10 pounds avoirdupois of distilled water at 62� of Fahrenheit, and barometer at 30 inches, equal to 277.274 cubic inches.
entry.ety: OF galon jalon, LL. galo galona, fr. galum a liquid measure; cf. F. jale large bowl. Cf. Gill a measure
entry.def: A measure of capacity, containing four quarts; -- used, for the most part, in liquid measure, but sometimes in dry measure.

entry.ety: From F. or Sp. galon. See Gala.

sn.def: A narrow tapelike fabric used for binding hats, shoes, etc., -- sometimes made ornamental.
A similar bordering or binding of rich material, such as gold lace.
sn.q: Silver and gold galloons, with the like glittering gewgaws.

entry.def: Furnished or adorned with galloon.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Galloped; p. pr. & vb. n. Galloping
entry.ety: OE. galopen, F. galoper, of German origin; cf. assumed Goth. ga-hlaupan to run, OHG. giloufen, AS. gehleápan to leap, dance, fr. root of E. leap, and a prefix; or cf. OFlem. walop a gallop. See Leap, and cf. 1st Wallop

sn.def: To move or run in the mode called a gallop; as a horse; to go at a gallop; to run or move with speed.
sn.q: But gallop lively down the western hill.

sn.def: To ride a horse at a gallop.
Fig.: To go rapidly or carelessly, as in making a hasty examination.
sn.q: Such superficial ideas he may collect in galloping over it.

entry.def: To cause to gallop.

cs.cd: a slow or gentle gallop.

entry.ety: Cf. F. galop. See Gallop v. i., and cf. Galop
entry.def: A mode of running by a quadruped, particularly by a horse, by lifting alternately the fore feet and the hind feet, in successive leaps or bounds.

entry.ety: F. galopade. See Gallop n.

sn.def: I horsemanship, a sidelong or curveting kind of gallop.
A kind of dance; also, music to the dance; a galop.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Gallopaded; p. pr. & vb. n. Gallopading

sn.def: To gallop, as on horseback.
To perform the dance called gallopade.

cs.cd: a light gun, supported on a galloper, -- formerly attached to British infantry regiments.

sn.def: One who, or that which, gallops.
A carriage on which very small guns were formerly mounted, the gun resting on the shafts, without a limber.

entry.ety: F. galopin. See Gallop v. i.
entry.def: An under servant for the kitchen; a scullion; a cook's errand boy.
Going at a gallop; progressing rapidly; as, a galloping horse.

entry.cs: Gallotannic acid. See Tannic acid, under Tannic.
entry.ety: Gall nutgall + tannic
entry.def: Pertaining to the tannin or nutgalls.

entry.ety: Cf. AS. āgelwan to stupefy
entry.def: To fright or terrify. See Gally v. t.
A small horse of a breed raised at Galloway, Scotland; -- called also garran, and garron.

entry.ety: Ir. galloglach. Cf. Gillie
entry.def: A heavy-armed foot soldier from Ireland and the Western Isles in the time of Edward �

entries.entry:
Gal"lows
Gallows bird a person who deserves the gallows. Colloq Gallows bitts Naut one of two or more frames amidships on deck for supporting spare spars; -- called also gallows gallows top gallows frame, etc. Gallows frame. The frame supporting the beam of an engine. Naut Gallows bitts. Gallows treeorGallow tree the gallows.
n. sing.; pl.Gallowses #orGallows. OE. galwes, pl., AS. galga gealga, gallows, cross; akin to D. galg gallows, OS. & OHG. galgo, G. galgen, Icel. gālgi, Sw. & Dan. galge, Goth. galga a cross. Etymologically and historically considered, gallows is a noun in the plural number, but it is used as a singular, and hence is preceded by a; as, a gallows
A frame from which is suspended the rope with which criminals are executed by hanging, usually consisting of two upright posts and a crossbeam on the top; also, a like frame for suspending anything. So they hanged Haman on the gallows. If I hang, I'll make a fat pair of gallows. O, there were desolation of gaolers and gallowses!
A wretch who deserves the gallows. R
Print The rest for the tympan when raised.
pl. A pair of suspenders or braces. Colloq At length him nailéd on a gallow tree.

entry.def: same as gallows.
entry.syn: gallows, gibbet, gallows tree, gallow tree.

entry.def: A concretion, or calculus, formed in the gall bladder or biliary passages. See Calculus n., 1.

entry.ety: See Gallow v. t.
entry.def: To frighten; to worry.
Like gall; bitter as gall.
See Galley n., 4.
See Galligaskins.

entry.ety: OE. galoche galache galage, shoe, F. galoche galoche, perh. altered fr. L. gallica a Gallic shoe, or fr. LL. calopedia wooden shoe, or shoe with a wooden sole, Gr. �, dim. of �, �, a shoemaker's last; � wood + � foot

sn.def: A clog or patten.
sn.q: Nor were worthy [to] unbuckle his galoche.

sn.def: An overshoe worn in wet weather, especially a waterproof rubber overshoe extending over the ankle, worn over one's regular shoes; now usually written galosh. It is used mostly in the plural.
A gaiter, or legging, covering the upper part of the shoe and part of the leg.

entry.def: A noisy, swaggering, or worthless fellow; a rowdy.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A kind of lively dance, in 2-4 time; also, the music to the dance.

entry.ety: Scot. gelore gilore galore, fr. Gael. gu leòr, enough; gu- to, also an adverbial prefix + leòr leòir, enough; or fr. Ir. goleor, the same word
entry.def: Plenty; abundance; in abundance.

sn.def: Same as Galoche Galoshe.
A strip of material, as leather, running around a shoe at and above the sole, as for protection or ornament.

entry.def: Same as Galoche.
To gape,; to yawn.

entry.ety: Gall bitterness + some
entry.def: Angry; malignant.

entry.ety: See Gault
entry.def: Same as Gault.

entry.cs:
Galvanic battery Elec an apparatus for generating electrical currents by the mutual action of certain liquids and metals; -- now usually called voltaic battery. See Battery.
Galvanic circuitorGalvanic circle . Elec See under Circuit. Galvanic pile Elec the voltaic pile. See under Voltaic.
entry.ety: From Galvani, a professor of physiology at Bologna, on account of his connection (about 1780) with the discovery of dynamical or current electricity: cf. F. galvanique
entry.def: Of or pertaining to, or exhibiting the phenomena of, galvanism; employing or producing electrical currents.

entry.note: ☞ The words galvanism and galvanic, formerly in very general use, are now rarely employed. For the latter, voltaic, from the name of Volta, is commonly used.
entry.ety: From Galvani: cf. F. galvanisme. See Galvanic
entry.def: Electricity excited by the mutual action of certain liquids and metals; dynamical electricity.
The branch of physical science which treats of dynamical elecricity, or the properties and effects of electrical currents.
One versed in galvanism.
The act of process of galvanizing.

cs.cd: formerly, iron coated with zink by electrical deposition; now more commonly, iron coated with zink by plunging into a bath of melted zink, after its surface has been cleaned by friction with the aid of dilute acid.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Galvanized; p pr. & vb. n. Galvanizing
entry.ety: Cf. F. galvaniser

sn.def: To affect with galvanism; to subject to the action of electrical currents.
To plate, as with gold, silver, etc., by means of electricity.
To restore to consciousness by galvanic action (as from a state of suspended animation); hence, to stimulate or excite to a factitious animation or activity.
To coat, as iron, with zinc. See Galvanized iron.

entry.def: One who, or that which, galvanize.

entry.ety: Galvanic + caustic
entry.def: Relating to the use of galvanic heat as a caustic, especially in medicine.
Cautery effected by a knife or needle heated by the passage of a galvanic current.

entry.ety: Galvanic + Gr. � to engrave
entry.def: Same as Glyphography.

entry.ety: Galvanic + -graph
entry.def: A copperplate produced by the method of galvanography; also, a picture printed from such a plate.
Of or pertaining to galvanography.

entry.ety: Galvanic + -graphy

sn.def: The art or process of depositing metals by electricity; electrotypy.
A method of producing by means of electrotyping process (without etching) copperplates which can be printed from in the same manner as engraved plates.

entry.def: One who describes the phenomena of galvanism; a writer on galvanism.

entry.ety: Galvanic + -logy
entry.def: A treatise on galvanism, or a description of its phenomena.

entry.cs:
Differential galvanometer. See under Differental a.
Sine galvanometer Cosine galvanometer Tangent galvanometer
Elec a galvanometer in which the sine, cosine, or tangent respectively, of the angle through which the needle is deflected, is proportional to the strength of the current passed through the instrument.
entry.ety: Galvanic + -meter: cf. F. galvanomètre
entry.def: An instrument or apparatus for measuring the intensity of an electric current, usually by the deflection of a magnetic needle.
Of, pertaining to, or measured by, a galvanometer.
The art or process of measuring the force of electric currents.

entry.ety: Galvanic + -plastic
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the art or process of electrotyping; employing, or produced by, the process of electolytic deposition; as, a galvano-plastic copy of a medal or the like.

entry.ety: Cf. F. galanoplastie
entry.def: The art or process of electrotypy.
Same as Electro-puncture.

entry.ety: Galvanic + -scope: cf. F. galvanoscope
entry.def: An instrument or apparatus for detecting the presence of electrical currents, especially such as are of feeble intensity.
Of or pertaining to a galvanoscope.
The use of galvanism in physiological experiments.

entry.ety: NL., fr. E. galvanic + Gr. � to tone
entry.def: Same as Electrotonus.

entry.ety: Galvanic + Gr. � to turn
entry.def: The tendency of a root to place its axis in the line of a galvanic current.
Gallows.

entry.ety: Orig. uncert., perh. from gammon, talk

sn.def: A herd, or school, of whales.
A visit between whalers at sea; a holding of social intercourse between those on different vessels at sea, or (Local U. S.) between persons ashore.
A visit between whalers at sea; a holding of social intercourse between those on different vessels at sea, or (Local U. S.) between persons ashore.

entry.ety: fr. gamba leg
entry.def: a leg.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Gammed; p. pr. & vb. n. Gam"ming

To engage in a gam, or (Local, U. S.) in social intercourse anywhere.
To have a gam with; to pay a visit to, esp. among whalers at sea.

entries.entry: Ga"ma grass`. From Gama, a cluster of the Maldive Islands Bot A species of grass (Tripsacum dactyloides) tall, stout, and exceedingly productive; cultivated in the West Indies, Mexico, and the Southern States of North America as a forage grass; -- called also sesame grass.

entry.ety: F. gamaches
entry.def: High boots or buskins; in Scotland, short spatterdashes or riding trousers, worn over the other clothing.
A viola da gamba.

entry.ety: I. or Sp. gamba leg. See Gambol n.
entry.def: Same as Gamashes.
entry.q: His thin legs tenanted a pair of gambadoes fastened at the side with rusty clasps.

entry.ety: Cf. F. gambier a kind of hook
entry.def: To gaff, as mackerel.
Same as Gambison.

entry.ety: Fr. gambette, or It. gambetta
entry.def: Any bird of the genuis Totanus. See Tattler.

entry.ety: Malayan
entry.def: The inspissated juice of a plant (Uncaria Gambir) growing in Malacca. It is a powerful astringent, and, under the name of Terra Japonica, is used for chewing with the Areca nut, and is exported for tanning and dyeing.
Catechu.

entry.ety: OF. gambeson gambaison, fr. gambais wambais, of German origin: cf. MHG. wambeis, G. wams doublet, fr. OHG. wamba, stomach. See Womb
entry.def: A defensive garment formerly in use for the body, made of cloth stuffed and quilted.

entry.ety: It. gamba leg
entry.def: A performer upon the viola di gamba. See under Viola.

entry.ety: F. gambit, cf. It. gambitto gambit, a tripping up. See Gambol n.
entry.def: A mode of opening the game, in which a pawn is sacrificed to gain an attacking position.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Gambled; p. pr. & vb. n. Gambling
entry.ety: Dim. of game. See 2d Game
entry.def: To play or game for money or other stake.
To lose or squander by gaming; -- usually with away.
entry.q: Bankrupts or sots who havegambledor slept away their estates.

entry.def: An act of gambling; a transaction or proceeding involving gambling; hence, anything involving similar risk or uncertainty.
One who gambles.

entry.ety: p. pr. of gamble
entry.def: the act of playing for stakes in the hope of winning (including the payment of a price for a chance to win a prize); as, his gambling cost him a fortune.

entry.note: ☞ There are several kinds of gamboge, but all are derived from species of Garcinia, a genus of trees of the order Guttiferæ. The best Siam gamboge is thought to come from Garcinia Hanburii . Ceylon gamboge is from G. Morella . G. pictoria , of Western India, yields gamboge, and also a kind of oil called gamboge butter.
entry.def: A concrete juice, or gum resin, produced by several species of trees in Siam, Ceylon, and Malabar. It is brought in masses, or cylindrical rolls, from Cambodia, or Cambogia, -- whence its name. The best kind is of a dense, compact texture, and of a beatiful reddish yellow. Taken internally, it is a strong and harsh cathartic and emetic.
Pertaining to, resembling, or containing, gamboge.

entry.ety: OE. gambolde gambaulde, F. gambade, gambol, fr. It. gambata kick, fr. L. gamba leg, akin to F. jambe, OF. also, gambe, fr. L. gamba, hoof or perh. joint: cf. Gr. � a binding, winding, W., Ir. & Gael. cam crooked; perhaps akin to E. chamber: cf.F. gambiller to kick about. Cf. Jamb n. Gammon ham, Gambadoes
entry.def: A skipping or leaping about in frolic; a hop; a sportive prank.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Gamboled, or Gambolled; p. pr. & vb. n. Gamboling or Gambolling
entry.def: To dance and skip about in sport; to frisk; to skip; to play in frolic, like boys or lambs.

cs.cd: a curb roof having the same section in all parts, with a lower steeper slope and an upper and flatter one, so that each gable is pentagonal in form.

entry.ety: OF. gambe jambe leg, F. jambe. Cf. Cambrel Chambrel, and see Gambol. n.

sn.def: The hind leg of a horse.
A stick crooked like a horse's hind leg; -- used by butchers in suspending slaughtered animals.

entry.def: To truss or hang up by means of a gambrel.
A kind of twilled linen cloth for lining.
A genus of fish including some of the mosquitofish.

entry.ety: Cf. W. cam crooked, and E. gambol n.
entry.def: Crooked; lame; as, a game leg.

entry.note: ☞ Among the ancients, especially the Greeks and Romans, there were regularly recurring public exhibitions of strength, agility, and skill under the patronage of the government, usually accompanied with religious ceremonies. Such were the Olympic, the Pythian, the Nemean, and the Isthmian games.
entry.cs: Confidence game. See under Confidence. To make game of to make sport of; to mock. Milton.
entry.ety: OE. game gamen, AS. gamen gomen, play, sport; akin to OS., OHG., & Icel. gaman, Dan. gammen mirth, merriment, OSw. gamman joy. Cf. Gammon a game, Backgammon Gamble v. i.

sn.def: Sport of any kind; jest, frolic.
sn.q: We have had pastimes here, and pleasant game.

sn.def: A contest, physical or mental, according to certain rules, for amusement, recreation, or for winning a stake; as, a game of chance; games of skill; field games, etc.
sn.q: But war's a game, which, were their subject wise, Kings would not play at.

sn.def: The use or practice of such a game; a single match at play; a single contest; as, a game at cards.
sn.q: Talk the game o'er between the deal.

sn.def: That which is gained, as the stake in a game; also, the number of points necessary to be scored in order to win a game; as, in short whist five points are game .
In some games, a point credited on the score to the player whose cards counts up the highest.
A scheme or art employed in the pursuit of an object or purpose; method of procedure; projected line of operations; plan; project.
sn.q: Your murderous game is nearly up.
It was obviously Lord Macaulay's game to blacken the greatest literary champion of the cause he had set himself to attack.

sn.def: Animals pursued and taken by sportsmen; wild meats designed for, or served at, table.
sn.q: Those species of animals . . . distinguished from the rest by the well-known appellation of game.

entry.cs: Game bag a sportsman's bag for carrying small game captured; also, the whole quantity of game taken. Game bird any bird commonly shot for food, esp. grouse, partridges, quails, pheasants, wild turkeys, and the shore or wading birds, such as plovers, snipe, woodcock, curlew, and sandpipers. The term is sometimes arbitrarily restricted to birds hunted by sportsmen, with dogs and guns. Game egg an egg producing a gamecock. Game laws laws regulating the seasons and manner of taking game for food or for sport. Game preserver a land owner who regulates the killing of game on his estate with a view to its increase. Eng To be game. To show a brave, unyielding spirit. To be victor in a game. Colloq To die game to maintain a bold, unyielding spirit to the last; to die fighting.

sn.def: Having a resolute, unyielding spirit, like the gamecock; ready to fight to the last; plucky.
sn.q: I was game . . . .I felt that I could have fought even to the death.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to such animals as are hunted for game, or to the act or practice of hunting.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Gamed gāmd; p. pr. & vb. n. Gaming
entry.ety: OE. gamen game�en, to rejoice, AS. gamenian to play. See Game n.

sn.def: To rejoice; to be pleased; -- often used, in Old English, impersonally with dative.
sn.q: God loved he best with all his whole hearte At alle times, though him gamed or smarte.

sn.def: To play at any sport or diversion.

To play for a stake or prize; to use cards, dice, billiards, or other instruments, according to certain rules, with a view to win money or some other thing waged upon the issue of the contest; to gamble.

entry.def: a canvas or leather bag for carrying game (especially birds) killed by a hunter.
The male game fowl.

entries.entry: Game" fowl` gām"foul`. Zoöl A handsome breed of the common fowl, remarkable for the great courage and pugnacity of the males.

entry.def: Full of game or games.
One who has the care of game, especially in a park or preserve.
Destitute of game.
a license authorizing the bearer to kill a certain type of animal during a specified period of time.
In a plucky manner; spiritedly.
Endurance; pluck.
a game that involves gambling.
a recreation room for noisy activities (parties or children's play etc) or for table games.
a television program in which contestants compete for awards. The contestants are members of the public selected to participate on the show, and not employed by the producer of the show.
Gay; sportive; playful; frolicsome; merry.
entry.q: Gladness of the gamesome crowd.

entry.ety: Game + -ster

sn.def: A merry, frolicsome person.
A person who plays at games; esp., one accustomed to play for a stake; a gambler; one skilled in games.
sn.q: When lenity and cruelty play for a kingdom, the gentlest gamester is the soonest winner.

sn.def: A prostitute; a strumpet.

entry.def: A cell or organ in which gametes develop.

entry.pr: găm"ēt; gȧ*mēt"; the latter usually in compounds
entry.ety: Gr. gameth` wife, or game`ths husband, fr. gamei^n to marry
entry.def: A sexual cell or germ cell having a single set of unpaired chromosomes; a conjugating cell which unites with another of like or unlike character to form a new individual. In Bot. gamete designates esp. the similar sex cells of the lower thallophytes which unite by conjugation, forming a zygospore. The gametes of higher plants are of two sorts, spermmale) and eggfemale); their union is called fertilization, and the resulting zygote an oöspore. In Zoöl. gamete is most commonly used of the sexual cells of certain Protozoa, though also extended to the germ cells of higher forms.

entry.note: Game theory is used for modelling and analysis of various decision-making situations such as military strategy or business policy. The theoretical models study the interactions among opposing entities called "players," where different kinds of situation can arise, for which the probabilities of occurence are known. Also known is the set of decisions each player can take. When a player takes a decision he makes a gain or incurs a loss. Based on the available knowledge each player tries to adopt a "strategy" so as to maximize his gains. The entire procedure constitutes a game.
entry.def: A branch of mathematics that deals with strategies for maximizing gains or minimizing losses in competitive situations having defined constraints and involving random factors.
An immature animal or plant cell that develops into a gamete by meiosis.
A modified branch bearing gametangia as in the thalloid liverworts.

entry.ety: Gamete + Gr. fyto`n plant
entry.def: In the alternation of generations in plants, that generation or phase which bears sex organs and produces gametes. In the lower plants, as the algæ, the gametophyte is the conspicuous part of the plant body; in mosses it is the so-called moss plant; in ferns it is reduced to a small, early perishing body; and in seed plants it is usually microscopic or rudimentary.

sn.def: suggestive of sexual impropriety; as, he skips asterisks and gives you the gamey details.
sn.syn: blue, gamy, juicy, naughty, racy, risque, spicy, sexy.

sn.def: foul-smelling; -- used of the smell of game beginning to taint.
spirited and resolute.
sn.syn: game, gamy, gritty, mettlesome, spirited, spunky.

sn.def: willing to proceed or act.

entry.ety: Gr. � marriage
entry.def: Pertaining to, or resulting from, sexual connection; formed by the union of the male and female elements.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A neglected and untrained city boy; a young street Arab.
entry.q: In Japan, the gamins run after you, and say, 'Look at the Chinaman.'

entry.def: behavior or language bordering on indelicacy.
The act or practice of playing games for stakes or wagers; gambling.
The third letter (Γ, γ = Eng. G) of the Greek alphabet.
A cross formed of four capital gammas, formerly used as a mysterious ornament on ecclesiastical vestments, etc. See Fylfot.

entries.entry: Gam"ma ray. n. Physics A very penetrating electromagnetic ray not appreciably deflected by a magnetic or electric field, emitted by radioactive substances. Gamma rays are photons of electromagnetic radiation having a wavelength shorter than that of X-rays, (i. e. shorter than 0.1 nanometer) and are correspondingly more penetrating than X-rays. In addition to being given off in certain types of radioactive decay, they may be found in cosmic radiation, though they are largely absorbed by the earth's atmosphere. Gamma-ray detectors orbited above the atmosphere have found bursts of gamma radiation, in some cases associated with visually observed supernova explosions, but in most cases from unidentified sources.

entry.ety: Possibly contr. fr. godmother; but prob. fr. grammer for grandmother. Cf. Gaffer
entry.def: An old wife; an old woman; -- correlative of gaffer, an old man.

entry.ety: OF. gambon, F. jambon, fr. OF. gambe leg, F. jambe. See Gambol n., and cf. Ham
entry.def: The buttock or thigh of a hog, salted and smoked or dried; the lower end of a flitch.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Gammoned găm"mŭnd; p. pr. & vb. n. Gammoning
entry.def: To make bacon of; to salt and dry in smoke.

entry.ety: See 2d Game

sn.def: Backgammon.

A victory in the game of backgammon in which one player gammons another, i. e., the winner bears off all of his pieces before his opponent bears off any pieces; as, he won the match with three gammons in a row.
An imposition or hoax; humbug.

To beat in the game of backgammon, before an antagonist has been able to get his “men” or counters home and withdraw any of them from the board; as, to gammon a person. In certain variants of the game one who gammons an opponent scores twice the normal value of the game.
To impose on; to hoax; to cajole.

entry.ety: Etymol. unknown
entry.def: To fasten (a bowsprit) to the stem of a vessel by lashings of rope or chain, or by a band of iron.

cs.cd: in the style of gammoning lashing, that is, having the turns of rope crossed.
a hole cut through the knee of the head of a vessel for the purpose of gammoning the bowsprit.

entry.ety: From 5th Gammon
entry.def: The lashing or iron band by which the bowsprit of a vessel is secured to the stem to opposite the lifting action of the forestays.

entry.ety: From 4th Gammon
entry.def: The act of imposing upon or hoaxing a person.

entry.ety: Gr. � marriage + E. genesis
entry.def: The production of offspring by the union of parents of different sexes; sexual reproduction; -- the opposite of agamogenesis.
Relating to gamogenesis.

entry.ety: Gr. � marriage + morfh` form, shape
entry.def: That stage of growth or development in an organism, in which the reproductive elements are generated and matured in preparation for propagating the species.

entry.ety: Gr. � marriage + E. petalous: cf. F. gamopétale
entry.def: Having the petals united or joined so as to form a tube or cup; monopetalous.

entry.ety: Gr. � marriage + � leaf
entry.def: Composed of leaves united by their edges (coalescent).

entry.ety: Gr. � marriage + E. sepal
entry.def: Formed of united sepals; monosepalous.
A large umbrella; -- said to allude to Mrs. Gamp's umbrella, in Dickens's “Martin Chuzzlewit.”

entry.ety: F. gamme + ut the name of a musical note. F. gamme is fr. the name of the Greek letter �, which was used by Guido d'Arezzo to represent the first note of his model scale. See Gamma, and Ut
entry.def: The scale.

sn.def: Having the flavor of game, esp. of game kept uncooked till near the condition of tainting; high-flavored.
Showing an unyielding spirit to the last; plucky; furnishing sport; as, a gamy trout.
Same as gamey.

entry.note: ☞ Gan was formerly used with the infinitive to form compound imperfects, as did is now employed. Gan regularly denotes the singular; the plural is usually denoted by gunne or gonne.
Later writers use gan both for singular and plural.Yet at her speech their rages gan relent. Spenser.
entry.ety: See Gin v.
entry.def: Began; commenced.
entry.q: This man gan falli.e., fell) in great suspicion.
The little coines to their play gunne hiei. e., hied).

entry.ety: Sp., pertaining to gain, held in common, fr. ganancia gain
entry.def: Designating, pertaining to, or held under, the Spanish system of law (called ganancial system) which controls the title and disposition of the property acquired during marriage by the husband or wife.

entry.ety: Cf. F. ganche n., also Sp. & Pg. gancho hook, It. gancio
entry.def: To drop from a high place upon sharp stakes or hooks, as the Turks dropped malefactors, by way of punishment.
entry.q: Ganching, which is to let fall from on high upon hooks, and there to hang until they die.

entry.ety: AS. gandra ganra, akin to Prov. G. gander ganter, and E. goose gannet. See Goose
entry.def: The male of any species of goose.
Mohandas Gandhi, a Hindu nationalist and religious leader, who preached non-violent resistance to oppression.
of or pertaining to Mohandas Gandhi.

entry.ety: See Yawn
entry.def: To yawn; to gape.

entry.note: ☞ He is represented as a short, fat, red-colored man, with a large belly and the head of an elephant.
entry.def: The Hindu god of wisdom, prudence and prophesy; the remover of obstacles.

entry.note: ☞ Obsolete in English literature, but still used in the North of England, and also in Scotland.
entry.ety: AS. gangan, akin to OS. & OHG. gangan, Icel. ganga, Goth. gaggan; cf. Lith. żengti to walk, Skr. jaṅgha leg. √48. Cf. Go
entry.def: To go; to walk.

entry.note: Youth gangs often associate with particular areas in a city, and may turn violent when they feel their territory is encroached upon. In Los Angeles the Crips and the Bloods are large gangs antagonistic to each other.
entry.cs:
Gang boardorGang plank . Naut A board or plank, with cleats for steps, forming a bridge by which to enter or leave a vessel. A plank within or without the bulwarks of a vessel's waist, for the sentinel to walk on. Gang cask a small cask in which to bring water aboard ships or in which it is kept on deck.
Gang cultivator Gang plow
a cultivator or plow in which several shares are attached to one frame, so as to make two or more furrows at the same time. Gang days Rogation days; the time of perambulating parishes. See Gang weekbelow). Gang drill a drilling machine having a number of drills driven from a common shaft. Gang master a master or employer of a gang of workmen. Gang plank. See Gang boardabove). Gang plow. See Gang cultivatorabove). Gang press a press for operating upon a pile or row of objects separated by intervening plates. Gang saw a saw fitted to be one of a combination or gang of saws hung together in a frame or sash, and set at fixed distances apart. Gang tide. See Gang weekbelow). Gang tooth a projecting tooth. Obs Halliwell. Gang week Rogation week, when formerly processions were made to survey the bounds of parishes. Halliwell.
Live gangorRound gang
the Western and the Eastern names, respectively, for a gang of saws for cutting the round log into boards at one operation. Knight. Slabbing gang an arrangement of saws which cuts slabs from two sides of a log, leaving the middle part as a thick beam.
entry.ety: Icel. gangr a going, gang, akin to AS., D., G., & Dan. gang a going, Goth. gaggs street, way. See Gang v. i.

sn.def: A going; a course.

A number going in company; hence, a company, or a number of persons associated for a particular purpose; a group of laborers under one foreman; a squad; as, a gang of sailors; a chain gang; a gang of thieves.
A combination of similar implements arranged so as, by acting together, to save time or labor; a set; as, a gang of saws, or of plows.
A set; all required for an outfit; as, a new gang of stays.
The mineral substance which incloses a vein; a matrix; a gangue.

A group of teenagers or young adults forming a more or less formalized group associating for social purposes, in some cases requiring initiation rites to join; as, a teen gang; a youth gang; a street gang .
A group of persons organized for criminal purposes; a criminal organization; as, the Parker gang .
