cs.note: It originates in the westward equatorial current, due to the trade winds, is deflected northward by Cape St. Roque through the Gulf of Mexico, and flows parallel to the coast of North America, turning eastward off the island of Nantucket. Its average rate of flow is said to be about two miles an hour. The similar Japan current, or Kuro-Siwo, is sometimes called the Gulf Stream of the Pacific.
cs.cd: a branching seaweed (Sargassum bacciferum, or sea grape), having numerous berrylike air vessels, -- found in the Gulf Stream, in the Sargasso Sea, and elsewhere.

entry.ety: F. golfe, It. golfo, fr. Gr. ko`lpos bosom, bay, gulf, LGr. ko`lfos

sn.def: A hollow place in the earth; an abyss; a deep chasm or basin,
sn.q: He then surveyed Hell and the gulf between.
Between us and you there is a great gulf fixed.

sn.def: That which swallows; the gullet.
That which swallows irretrievably; a whirlpool; a sucking eddy.
sn.q: A gulf of ruin, swallowing gold.

sn.def: A portion of an ocean or sea extending into the land; a partially land-locked sea; as, the Gulf of Mexico.
A large deposit of ore in a lode.
A brown seaweed (Sargassum bacciferum) with rounded bladders forming dense floating masses in tropical Atlantic waters as in the Sargasso Sea.

entry.def: Full of whirlpools or gulfs.

entry.ety: Hind. galgal
entry.def: A cement made in India from sea shells, pulverized and mixed with oil, and spread over a ship's bottom, to prevent the boring of worms.

entry.ety: L. gulo
entry.def: A glutton.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Gulled gŭld; p. pr. & vb. n. Gulling
entry.ety: Prob. fr. gull the bird; but cf. OSw. gylla to deceive, D. kullen, and E. cullibility
entry.def: To deceive; to cheat; to mislead; to trick; to defraud.
entry.q: The rulgar, gulled into rebellion, armed.
I'm not gulling him for the emperor's service.

sn.def: A cheating or cheat; trick; fraud.
One easily cheated; a dupe.

entry.note: ☞ Among the best known American species are the herring gull (Larus argentatus), the great black-backed gull (L. murinus) the laughing gull (L. atricilla), and Bonaparte's gull (L. Philadelphia). The common European gull is Larus canus.

cs.cd: the jager; -- also applied to certain species of terns.

entry.ety: Of Celtic origin; cf. Corn. gullan, W. gwylan
entry.def: One of many species of long-winged sea birds of the genus Larus and allied genera.
Act of being gulled.
entry.q: Had you no quirk. To avoid gullage, sir, by such a creature?

entry.def: One who gulls; a deceiver.
An act, or the practice, of gulling; trickery; fraud.
entry.q: A meregullery.

entry.ety: OE. golet, OF. Goulet, dim. of gole goule throat, F. gueule, L. gula; perh. akin to Skr. gula, G. kenle; cf. F. goulet the neck of a bottle, goulotte channel gutter. Cf. Gules Gully

sn.def: The tube by which food and drink are carried from the pharynx to the stomach; the esophagus.

entry.sn:
Something shaped like the food passage, or performing similar functions; as: A channel for water.
Engin A preparatory cut or channel in excavations, of sufficient width for the passage of earth wagons.
A concave cut made in the teeth of some saw blades.

entry.def: A system of excavating by means of gullets or channels.
Easily gulled; that may be duped.
Foolish; stupid.

entries.entry:
Gul"ly n.; pl.Gulles #.
Etymol. uncertain
A large knife. Scot

Gul"ly
Gully gut a glutton. Obs Chapman. Gully hole the opening through which gutters discharge surface water.
n.; pl.Gullies #.
Formerly gullet
A channel or hollow worn in the earth by a current of water; a short deep portion of a torrent's bed when dry.
A grooved iron rail or tram plate. Eng

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Gullied #; p. pr. & vb. n. Gullying
entry.def: To wear into a gully or into gullies.
To flow noisily.

entry.ety: L. gulositas, fr. gulosus gluttonous. See Gullet
entry.def: Excessive appetite; greediness; voracity.

cs.cd: to throw up from the stomach; to disgorge.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Gulped; p. pr. & vb. n. Gulping
entry.ety: D. gulpen, cf. OD. golpe gulf
entry.def: To swallow eagerly, or in large draughts; to swallow up; to take down at one swallow.
entry.q: He does not swallow, but he gulps it down.
The old man . . . glibly gulped down the whole narrative.

sn.def: The act of taking a large mouthful; a swallow, or as much as is awallowed at once.
A disgorging.

entry.def: See Gulf.
Guilt. See Guilt.
Guilty.
Of or pertaining to gules; red.
entry.q: Those fatalgulydragons.

cs.cd: strophulus in a teething child; red gum.
a smooth hard substance for children to bite upon while teething.

entry.ety: OE. gome, AS. gama palate; akin Co G. gaumen, OHG. goumo guomo, Icel. g�mr, Sw. gom; cf. Gr. � to gape
entry.def: The dense tissues which invest the teeth, and cover the adjacent parts of the jaws.
To deepen and enlarge the spaces between the teeth of (a worn saw). See Gummer.

entry.cs:
Black gum Blue gum British gum, etc. See under Black Blue, etc. Gum Acaroidea the resinous gum of the Australian grass tree (Xanlhorrhœa). Gum animal Zoöl the galago of West Africa; -- so called because it feeds on gums. See Galago. Gum animi or animé. See Animé. Gum arabic , a gum yielded mostly by several species of Acaciachiefly A. vera and A. Arabica) growing in Africa and Southern Asia; -- called also gum acacia. East Indian gum arabic comes from a tree of the Orange family which bears the elephant apple. Gum butea a gum yielded by the Indian plants Butea frondosa and B. superba, and used locally in tanning and in precipitating indigo. Gum cistus a plant of the genus Cistus Cistus ladaniferus), a species of rock rose. Gum dragon. See Tragacanth.
Gum elastic Elastic gum . See Caoutchouc. Gum elemi. See Elemi. Gum juniper. See Sandarac. Gum kino. See under Kino. Gum lac. See Lac. Gum Ladanum , a fragrant gum yielded by several Oriental species of Cistus or rock rose. Gum passages sap receptacles extending through the parenchyma of certain plants (Amygdalaceæ Cactaceæ, etc.), and affording passage for gum. Gum pot , a varnish maker's utensil for melting gum and mixing other ingredients. Gum resin the milky juice of a plant solidified by exposure to air; one of certain inspissated saps, mixtures of, or having properties of, gum and resin; a resin containing more or less mucilaginous and gummy matter. Gum sandarac. See Sandarac. Gum Senegal , a gum similar to gum arabic, yielded by trees (Acacia Verek and A. Adansoniä) growing in the Senegal country, West Africa. Gum tragacanth. See Tragacanth. Gum water a solution of gum, esp. of gum arabic, in water. Gum wood the wood of any gum tree, esp. the wood of the Eucalyptus piperita, of New South Wales.
entry.ety: OE. gomme gumme, F. gomme, L. gummi and commis, fr. Gr. �, prob. from an Egyptian form kam�; cf. It. gomma

sn.def: A vegetable secretion of many trees or plants that hardens when it exudes, but is soluble in water; as, gum arabic; gum tragacanth; the gum of the cherry tree. Also, with less propriety, exudations that are not soluble in water; as, gum copal and gum sandarac, which are really resins.
See Gum tree below.
A hive made of a section of a hollow gum tree; hence, any roughly made hive; also, a vessel or bin made of a hollow log.
A rubber overshoe.

cs.cd: To block or clog (a conduit) with or as if with gum; as, to gum up the drainpipe.
to interfere with; to spoil.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Gummed gŭmd; p. pr. & vb. n. Gumming

sn.def: To smear with gum; to close with gum; to unite or stiffen by gum or a gumlike substance; to make sticky with a gumlike substance.
sn.q: He frets like a gummed velvet.

sn.def: To chew with the gums, rather than with the teeth.

entry.def: To exude or form gum; to become gummy.
A piece of chewing gum in the shape of a ball, usually covered with a colored glaze of sugar. They are often sold in a small, special-purpose coin-operated vending machine called a gumball machine.

entry.ety: Written also gombo

sn.def: A soup thickened with the mucilaginous pods of the okra; okra soup.
A thick stew made with chicken (chicken gumbo), or seafood (seafood gumbo), thickened with okra or file, and also containing greens and often hot spices; it is particularly popular in Louisiana.
The okra plant or its pods.

entry.def: A small suppurating inflamed spot on the gum.
A tropical American tree (Bursera simaruba) yielding a reddish resin used in cements and varnishes.
an inferior lac produced by lac insects in Madagascar.

entries.entry:
‖Gum"ma gŭm"mȧ n.; pl.Gummata #. NL. So called from its gummy contents See Gum
Med A kind of soft tumor, usually of syphilitic origin.

entry.def: Belonging to, or resembling, gumma.

entry.ety: From 2d Gum
entry.def: A punch-cutting tool, or machine for deepening and enlarging the spaces between the teeth of a worn saw.

entry.ety: L. gummi gum + -ferous
entry.def: Producing gum; gum-bearing.
The state or quality of being gummy; viscousness.

entry.ety: So called because it occurs in rounded or flattened pieces which look like gum
entry.def: A yellow amorphous mineral, essentially a hydrated oxide of uranium derived from the alteration of uraninite.
Gumminess; a viscous or adhesive quality or nature.

entry.ety: L. gummosus; cf. F. gommeux

sn.def: Gumlike, or composed of gum; gummy.
Of or pertaining to a gumma.

cs.cd: a gumma.

entry.ety: Compar. Gummer�); superl. Gummirst
entry.def: Consisting of gum; viscous; adhesive; producing or containing gum; covered with gum or a substance resembling gum.
entry.q: Kindles the gummy bark of fir or pine.
Then rubs his gummy eyes.

entry.ety: Cf. Sw. & Dan. gump buttocks, rump, Icel. gumpr
entry.def: A dolt; a dunce.

entry.ety: OE. gom gome, attention; akin to AS. geómian gyman, to regard, observe, gyme care, OS. gomean to heed, Goth. gaumjan to see, notice

sn.def: Capacity; shrewdness; common sense.
sn.q: One does not have gumption till one has been properly cheated.

sd.def: The art of preparing colors.
Megilp.

sn.def: initiative; resourcefulness.
Courage; guts.
enterprising.

entry.def: A piece of athletic equipment that protects an athlete's mouth.

sn.def: A detective; a private eye.
A shoe made of rubber, as a rubber overshoe.
A sneaker{3}.

entry.def: Any tree that exudes a gum,
The black gum (Nyssa multiflora), one of the largest trees of the Southern States, bearing a small blue fruit, the favorite food of the opossum. Most of the large trees become hollow.
A tree of the genus Eucalyptus; a eucalypt. See Eucalpytus.
The sweet gum tree of the United States (Liquidambar styraciflua), a large and beautiful tree with pointedly lobed leaves and woody burlike fruit. It exudes an aromatic terebinthine juice.
The sour gum tree.
any of various Western American plants of the genus Grindelia having resinous leaves and stems formerly used medicinally; often poisonous to livestock.
wood or lumber from any of various gum trees especially the sweet gum.

entry.note: ☞ Guns are classified, according to their construction or manner of loading as rifled or smoothbore breech-loading or muzzle-loading cast or built-up guns; or according to their use, as field mountain prairie seacoast, and siege guns.
entry.cs:
Armstrong gun a wrought iron breech-loading cannon named after its English inventor, Sir William Armstrong.
Big gunorGreat gun
a piece of heavy ordnance; hence (Fig.), a person superior in any way; as, bring in the big guns to tackle the problem. Gun barrel the barrel or tube of a gun. Gun carriage the carriage on which a gun is mounted or moved. Gun cotton Chem a general name for a series of explosive nitric ethers of cellulose, obtained by steeping cotton in nitric and sulphuric acids. Although there are formed substances containing nitric acid radicals, yet the results exactly resemble ordinary cotton in appearance. It burns without ash, with explosion if confined, but quietly and harmlessly if free and open, and in small quantity. Specifically, the lower nitrates of cellulose which are insoluble in ether and alcohol in distinction from the highest (pyroxylin) which is soluble. See Pyroxylin, and cf. Xyloidin. The gun cottons are used for blasting and somewhat in gunnery: for making celluloid when compounded with camphor; and the soluble variety (pyroxylin) for making collodion. See Celluloid, and Collodion. Gun cotton is frequenty but improperly called nitrocellulose. It is not a nitro compound, but an ester of nitric acid. Gun deck. See under Deck. Gun fire the time at which the morning or the evening gun is fired. Gun metal a bronze, ordinarily composed of nine parts of copper and one of tin, used for cannon, etc. The name is also given to certain strong mixtures of cast iron. Gun port Naut an opening in a ship through which a cannon's muzzle is run out for firing. Gun tackle Naut the blocks and pulleys affixed to the side of a ship, by which a gun carriage is run to and from the gun port. Gun tackle purchase Naut a tackle composed of two single blocks and a fall. Totten. Krupp gun a wrought steel breech-loading cannon, named after its German inventor, Herr Krupp. Machine gun a breech-loading gun or a group of such guns, mounted on a carriage or other holder, and having a reservoir containing cartridges which are loaded into the gun or guns and fired in rapid succession. In earlier models, such as the Gatling gun, the cartridges were loaded by machinery operated by turning a crank. In modern versions the loading of cartidges is accomplished by levers operated by the recoil of the explosion driving the bullet, or by the pressure of gas within the barrel. Several hundred shots can be fired in a minute by such weapons, with accurate aim. The Gatling gun Gardner gun Hotchkiss gun, and Nordenfelt gun, named for their inventors, and the French mitrailleuse, are machine guns. To blow great guns Naut to blow a gale. See Gun n., 3.
entry.ety: OE. gonne gunne; of uncertain origin; cf. Ir., Gael., & LL. gunna, W. gum; possibly (like cannon) fr. L. canna reed, tube; or abbreviated fr. OF. mangonnel, E. mangonel, a machine for hurling stones

sn.def: A weapon which throws or propels a missile to a distance; any firearm or instrument for throwing projectiles, consisting of a tube or barrel closed at one end, in which the projectile is placed, with an explosive charge (such as guncotton or gunpowder) behind, which is ignited by various means. Pistols, rifles, carbines, muskets, and fowling pieces are smaller guns, for hand use, and are called small arms. Larger guns are called cannon ordnance fieldpieces carronades howitzers, etc. See these terms in the Vocabulary.
sn.q: As swift as a pellet out of a gunne When fire is in the powder runne.
The word gun was in use in England for an engine to cast a thing from a man long before there was any gunpowder found out.

sn.def: A piece of heavy ordnance; in a restricted sense, a cannon.
Violent blasts of wind.

entry.def: To practice fowling or hunting small game; -- chiefly in participial form; as, to go gunning.

sn.def: To pursue with the intent to kill.
To make an effort to harm someone, especially with determination; -- also used humorously.

entry.ety: Skr. guna quality
entry.def: In Sanskrit grammar, a lengthening of the simple vowels aie, by prefixing an a element. The term is sometimes used to denote the same vowel change in other languages.
See Gynarchy.

sn.def: A vessel of light draught, carrying one or more guns, used for operations in shallow waters.
Any small naval vessel carrying mounted guns.

entries.entry: Gun"cot`ton. See under Gun.

entry.def: See Gondola.
A sharpened flint for the lock of a gun, to ignite the charge. It was in common use before the introduction of percussion caps.
See Ganja.
any thick gooey and messy substance.
entry.syn: goo, gook, guck, muck, ooze, sludge, slime.

entry.def: The mechanism of a gun for producing the discharge. See Lock.
The number of guns carried by a ship of war.

entry.ety: See Gunwale

sn.def: A gunwale.
A small, eel-shaped, marine fish of the genus Murænoides; esp., M. gunnellus of Europe and America; -- called also gunnel fish butterfish rock eel.

cs.cd: the gun to which men or boys were lashed for punishment.
A member of the crew of a bomber airplane who operates the defensive gun at the rear of the airplane.

sn.def: One who works a gun or cannon, whether on land, sea, or in the air; a cannoneer.
A warrant officer in the navy having charge of the ordnance on a vessel.

sd.def: The great northern diver or loon. See Loon.
The sea bream.

entry.def: That branch of military science which comprehends the theory of projectiles, and the manner of constructing and using ordnance.
Space left by the removal of ore.
The act or practice of hunting or shooting game with a gun.
entry.q: The art of gunning was but little practiced.

entries.entry:
Gun"ny gŭn"n� n. Gun"ny cloth`
Gunny bagorGunny sack
a sack made of gunny or burlap, used for coarse commodities. In the southern U. S. similar sacks are called crocus sack croker sack towsack, and grass sack.
klŏth`; 115. Hind. goṇ goṇī, a sack, sacking A strong, coarse kind of sacking, made from the fibers (called jute) of two plants of the genus Corchorus C. olitorius and C. capsularis), of India. The fiber is also used in the manufacture of cordage.

entry.def: See Gyneocracy.
An instance of the firing of small arms with the intent to kill or frighten.

sn.def: the muzzle's direction; as, he held me up at gunpoint .
the open discharging end of a gun.

entry.note: ☞ Gunpowder consists of from 70 to 80 per cent of niter, with 10 to 15 per cent of each of the other ingredients. Its explosive energy is due to the fact that it contains the necessary amount of oxygen for its own combustion, and liberates gases (chiefly nitrogen and carbon dioxide), which occupy a thousand or fifteen hundred times more space than the powder which generated them.

cs.cd: a pile driver, the hammer of which is thrown up by the explosion of gunpowder.

a plot to destroy the King, Lords, and Commons, in revenge for the penal laws against Catholics. As Guy Fawkes, the agent of the conspirators, was about to fire the mine, which was placed under the House of Lords, he was seized, Nov. 5, 1605. Hence, Nov. 5 is known in England as Guy Fawkes Day.
a species of fine green tea, each leaf of which is rolled into a small ball or pellet.

entry.def: A black, granular, explosive substance, consisting of an intimate mechanical mixture of saltpeter, charcoal, and sulphur. It is used in gunnery and blasting.
The reach or distance to which a gun will shoot; gunshot.
An apartment on the after end of the lower gun deck of a ship of war, usually occupied as a messroom by the commissioned officers, except the captain; -- called wardroom in the United States navy.

sn.def: Act of firing a gun; a shot.
The distance to which shot can be thrown from a gun, so as to be effective; the reach or range of a gun.
sn.q: Those who are come over to the royal party are supposed to be out of gunshot.

entry.def: Made by the shot of a gun: as. a gunshot wound.
A sight{9} attached to a gun, used for aiming it at the target. Same as sight9}.
One whose occupation is to make or repair small firearms; an armorer.
The art or business of a gunsmith.
A stick to ram down the charge of a musket, etc.; a rammer or ramrod.
The stock or wood to which the barrel of a hand gun is fastened.
A cannon ball; -- so called because originally made of stone.

entries.entry: Gun"ter rig`. Naut A topmast arranged with metal bands so that it will readily slide up and down the lower mast.
Gun"ter's chain`. Surveying The chain ordinarily used in measuring land. See Chain n., 4, and Gunter's scale.
Gun"ter's line`. A logarithmic line on Gunter's scale, used for performing the multiplication and division of numbers mechanically by the dividers; -- called also line of lines, and line of numbers.

Gun"ter's quad`rant. A thin quadrant, made of brass, wood, etc., showing a stereographic projection on the plane of the equator. By it are found the hour of the day, the sun's azimuth, the altitude of objects in degrees, etc. See Gunter's scale.

Gun"ter's scale` ☞ Gunter's scale is a wooden rule, two feet long, on one side of which are marked scales of equal parts, of chords, sines, tangents, rhombs, etc., and on the other side scales of logarithms of these various parts, by means of which many problems in surveying and navigation may be solved, mechanically, by the aid of dividers alone.. A scale invented by the Rev. Edmund Gunter1581-1626), a professor of astronomy at Gresham College, London, who invented also Gunter's chain, and Gunter's quadrant.

entry.ety: Gun + wale. So named because the upper guns were pointed from it
entry.def: The upper edge of a vessel's or boat's side; the uppermost wale of a ship (not including the bulwarks); or that piece of timber which reaches on either side from the quarter-deck to the forecastle, being the uppermost bend, which finishes the upper works of the hull.

entry.ety: Named after R. J. L. Guppy , who brought speciments to the British museum. RHUD
entry.def: A small freshwater fish of South America and West Indies (Lebistes reticulatus or Poecilia reticulata, originaly called Gerardinus guppyi), often kept in aquariums; also called rainbow fish.

entry.ety: L. gurges
entry.def: A whirlpool.
entry.q: The plain, wherein a black bituminous gurge Boils out from under ground.

entry.ety: See Gorge
entry.def: To swallow up.
See Grudgeons.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Gurgled;p. pr. & vb. n. Gurgling
entry.ety: Cf. It. gorgogliare to gargle, bubble up, fr. L. gurgulio gullet. Cf. Gargle Gorge
entry.def: To run or flow in a broken, irregular, noisy current, as water from a bottle, or a small stream among pebbles or stones.
entry.q: Pure gurgling rills the lonely desert trace, And waste their music on the savage race.

entry.def: The act of gurgling; a broken, bubbling noise.
entry.q: Tinklinggurgles.

entry.ety: See Goglet
entry.def: A porous earthen jar for cooling water by evaporation.
In a gurgling manner.
See Gargoyle.
A thin balsam or wood oil derived from the Diptcrocarpus lævis, an East Indian tree. It is used in medicine, and as a substitute for linseed oil in the coarser kinds of paint.
A young person of either sex. See Girl.
A pickax with one sharp point and one cutting edge.
A level; a working.

entry.cs: Plyling gurnard. See under Flying.
entry.ety: OF. gornal gournal gornart, perh. akin to F. grogner to grunt; cf. Ir. guirnead gurnard
entry.def: One ofseveral European marine fishes, of the genus Trigla and allied genera, having a large and spiny head, with mailed cheeks. Some of the species are highly esteemed for food. The name is sometimes applied to the American sea robins.
See Gwiniad.
An alvine evacuation; also, refuse matter.

entry.ety: Hind. garhī
entry.def: A small fort.
A gutter or channel for water, hewn out of the bottom of a working drift.

entry.ety: Cf. Grout
entry.def: Groats.
Same as gooroo.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Gushed gŭsht; p. pr. & vb. n. Gushing
entry.ety: OE. guschen, cf. Icel. gusa and gjsa, also D. gucsen; perh. akin to AS. geótan to pour, G. giessen, Goth. giutan, E. gut. Cf. Found to cast

sn.def: To issue with violence and rapidity, as a fluid; to rush forth as a fluid from confinement; to flow copiously.
sn.q: He smote the rock that the waters gushed out.
A sea of blood gushed from the gaping wound.

sn.def: To make a sentimental or untimely exhibition of affection; to display enthusiasm in a silly, demonstrative manner.

A sudden and violent issue of a fluid from an inclosed plase; an emission of a liquid in a large quantity, and with force; the fluid thus emitted; a rapid outpouring of anything; as, a gush of song from a bird.
sn.q: The gush of springs, An fall of lofty foundains.

sn.def: A sentimental exhibition of affection or enthusiasm, etc.; effusive display of sentiment.

entry.def: One who gushes.

sn.def: Rushing forth with violence, as a fluid; flowing copiously; as, gushing waters.
sn.q: Gushingblood.

sn.def: Emitting copiously, as tears or words; weakly and unreservedly demonstrative in matters of affection; sentimental.
In a gushing manner; copiously.
Weakly; sentimentally; effusively.
extravagantly demonstrative; gushing{2}; as, to write unrestrained and gushy poetry.

entry.ety: F. gousset armpit, fob, gusset, dim. of gousse pod, husk; cf. It. guscio shell, or W. cwysed gore, gusset

sn.def: A small piece of cloth inserted in a garment, for the purpose of strengthening some part or giving it a tapering enlargement.
sn.q: Seam and gusset and band.

entry.sn:
Anything resembling a gusset in a garment; as: Armor A small piece of chain mail at the openings of the joints beneath the arms.
Mach A kind of bracket, or angular piece of iron, fastened in the angles of a structure to give strength or stiffness; esp., the part joining the barrel and the fire box of a locomotive boiler.

sn.def: An abatement or mark of dishonor in a coat of arms, resembling a gusset.

entry.def: provided or reinforced with gussets. Opposite of ungusseted.
dressed up; well-dressed; as, all gussied up in sequins and feathers.
entry.syn: fancied up, gussied up, tricked out.

entry.ety: Icel. gustr a cool breeze. Cf. Gush

sn.def: A sudden squall; a violent blast of wind; a sudden and brief rushing or driving of the wind.
sn.q: Snow, and hail, stormy gust and flaw.

sn.def: A sudden violent burst of passion.

entry.ety: L. gustus; cf. It. & Sp. gusto. √46

sn.def: The sense or pleasure of tasting; relish; gusto.
sn.q: An ox will relish the tender flesh of kids with as much gust and appetite.

sn.def: Gratification of any kind, particularly that which is exquisitely relished; enjoyment.
sn.q: Destroy all creatures for thy sport or gust.

sn.def: Intellectual taste; fancy.
sn.q: A choice of it may be made according to the gust and manner of the ancients.

entry.ety: Cf. L. gustare, It. gustare, Sp. gustar. See GUST a relish
entry.def: To taste; to have a relish for.

entry.ety: See Gust v.

sn.def: Capable of being tasted; tastable.
sn.q: This position informs us of a vulgar error, terming the gall bitter; whereas there is nothing gustable sweeter.

sn.def: Pleasant to the taste; toothsome; savory.
sn.q: A gustable thing, seen or smelt, excites the appetite, and affects the glands and parts of the mouth.

entry.def: Anything that can be tasted.
The great bustard.

entry.ety: L. gustatio: cf. F. gustation
entry.def: The act of tasting.
of or pertaining to taste.
Pertaining to, or subservient to, the sense of taste; as, the gustatory nerve which supplies the front of the tongue.
Tasteful; well-tasted.
Gusty.
entry.q: A gustful April morn.

entry.def: Tasteless; insipid.

entry.ety: It. or Sp., fr. L. gustus; akin to E. choose. Cf. 2d Gust Goût
entry.def: Nice or keen appreciation or enjoyment; relish; taste; fancy; as, he ate it with gusto .

entry.ety: It
entry.def: Tasteful; in a tasteful, agreeable manner.
Subject to, or characterized by, gusts or squalls; windy; stormy; tempestuous.
entry.q: Upon a raw and gusty day.

entry.cs: Blind gut. See CÆcum n..
entry.ety: OE. gut got, AS. gut, prob. orig., a channel, and akin to geótan to pour. See FOUND to cast

sn.def: A narrow passage of water; as, the Gut of Canso.
An intenstine; a bowel; the whole alimentary canal; the enteron; (pl.) bowels; entrails.
One of the prepared entrails of an animal, esp. of a sheep, used for various purposes. See Catgut.
The sac of silk taken from a silkworm (when ready to spin its cocoon), for the purpose of drawing it out into a thread. This, when dry, is exceedingly strong, and is used as the snood of a fish line.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Gutted; p. pr. & vb. n. Gutting

sn.def: To take out the bowels from; to eviscerate.
To plunder of contents; to destroy or remove the interior or contents of; as, a mob gutted the house.
sn.q: Tom Brown, of facetious memory, having gutted a proper name of its vowels, used it as freely as he pleased.

entry.def: lacking courage or vitality; as, he was a yellow gutless worm. Opposite of gutsy.

sn.def: marked by courage and determination in the face of difficulties or danger.
rough or plain; not sophisticated or refined; earthy. Opposite of sophisticated, or refined.

entries.entry:
‖Gut"ta
Gutta serena L., lit. serene or clear drop Med amaurosis. Guttæ band Arch the listel or band from which the guttæ hang.
n.; pl.GuttÆ #. L
A drop.
Arch One of a series of ornaments, in the form of a frustum of a cone, attached to the lower part of the triglyphs, and also to the lower faces of the mutules, in the Doric order; -- called also campana, and drop.

entry.ety: Malay gutah gum + pertja the tree from which is it procured
entry.def: A concrete juice produced by various trees found in the Malayan archipelago, especially by the Isonandra Gutta, syn. Dichopsis Gutta. It becomes soft, and unpressible at the tamperature of boiling water, and, on cooling, retains its new shape. It dissolves in oils and ethers, but not in water. In many of its properties it resembles caoutchouc, and it is extensively used for many economical purposes. The Mimusops globosa of Guiana also yields this material.

entry.ety: L. guttatus. Cf. Gutty
entry.def: Spotted, as if discolored by drops.

entry.ety: See Guttate
entry.def: Besprinkled with drops, or droplike spots.
The inspissated juice of a tree of the genus Artocarpus A. incisa, or breadfruit tree), sometimes used in making birdlime, on account of its glutinous quality.

cs.cd: an architectural member made by treating the outside face of the gutter in a decorative fashion, or by crowning it with ornaments, regularly spaced, like a diminutive battlement.
a carpenter's plane with a rounded bottom for planing out gutters.
a neglected boy running at large; a street Arab.
one of the pieces of furniture which separate pages in a form.

entry.ety: OE. gotere, OF. goutiere, F. gouttière, fr. OF. gote goute, drop, F. goutte, fr. L. gutta

sn.def: A channel at the eaves of a roof for conveying away the rain; an eaves channel; an eaves trough.
A small channel at the roadside or elsewhere, to lead off surface water.
sn.q: Gutters running with ale.

sn.def: Any narrow channel or groove; as, a gutter formed by erosion in the vent of a gun from repeated firing.

Either of two sunken channels at either side of the bowling alley, leading directly to the sunken pit behind the pins. Balls not thrown accurately at the pins will drop into such a channel bypassing the pins, and resulting in a score of zero for that bowl.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Guttered #; p. pr. & vb. n. Guttering

sn.def: To cut or form into small longitudinal hollows; to channel.
To supply with a gutter or gutters.

entry.def: To become channeled, as a candle when the flame flares in the wind.
A bowl in which the ball falls into the gutter{4}, resulting in a score of zero for that bowl.

sd.def: A small poster, suitable for a curbstone.
A curbstone broker.

sn.def: same as street Arab.
a person of low moral character.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L. gutta drop+ ferre to bear
entry.def: A plant that exudes gum or resin.
Yielding gum or resinous substances.
Pertaining to a natural order of trees and shrubs (Guttiferæ) noted for their abounding in a resinous sap.

entry.ety: L. gutta a drop + -form
entry.def: Drop-shaped, as a spot of color.

entry.ety: From Gut n.
entry.def: To put into the gut; to swallow greedily; to gorge; to gormandize.
A greedy eater; a glutton.

entry.ety: L. guttula a little drop, dim. of gutta drop
entry.def: In droplike form.
entry.q: In its [hail'sguttulous descent from the air.

entry.ety: L. guttur throat: cf. F. gutural
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the throat; formed in the throat; relating to, or characteristic of, a sound formed in the throat.
entry.q: Children are occasionally born with guttural swellings.
In such a sweet, guttural accent.

entry.def: A sound formed in the throat; esp., a sound formed by the aid of the back of the tongue, much retracted, and the soft palate; also, a letter representing such a sound.
The quality of being guttural; as, the gutturalism of A [in the 16th cent.
The quality of being guttural.
entry.q: The oldgutturalityof k.

entry.def: To speak gutturally; to give a guttural sound to.
In a guttural manner.
The quality of being guttural.

entry.ety: L. guttur throat
entry.def: Pertaining to the throat.
entry.q: Gutturine tumor.

entry.ety: L. guttur throat
entry.def: To make in the throat; to gutturalize.
entry.q: For which the Germans gutturize a sound.

entries.entry: Gut"tur*o-. A combining form denoting relation to the throat; as, gutturo-nasal, having both a guttural and a nasal character; gutturo-palatal.

entry.ety: L. gutta drop: cf. F. goutté. Cf. Guttated
entry.def: Charged or sprinkled with drops.
A plant, Globularia Alypum, a violent purgative, found in Africa.

entry.ety: Sp. guia guide, a guy or small rope used on board of ships to keep weighty things in their places; of Teutonic origin, and the same word as E. guide. See Guide, and cf. Gye
entry.def: A rope, chain, or rod attached to anything to steady it; as: a rope to steady or guide an object which is being hoisted or lowered; a rope which holds in place the end of a boom, spar, or yard in a ship; a chain or wire rope connecting a suspension bridge with the land on either side to prevent lateral swaying; a rod or rope attached to the top of a structure, as of a derrick, and extending obliquely to the ground, where it is fastened.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. guyed gīd; p. pr. & vb. n. guying
entry.def: To steady or guide with a guy.

sn.def: A grotesque effigy, like that of Guy Fawkes, dressed up in England on the fifth of November, the day of the Gunpowder Plot.
sn.q: The lady . . . who dresses like a guy.

sn.def: A person of queer looks or dress.
A man or young man; a fellow; -- usually contrasted with gals or girls as, it was fun for both the guys and gals; the guys were watching football while the girls played bridge.
A member of a group of either sex, usually a friend or comrade; -- usually used in the pl.; as, tell the guys to come inside; are any of you guys interested in a game of tennis?.

entry.def: To fool; to baffle; to make (a person) an object of ridicule.

sn.def: of or pertaining to Guyana; as, Jonestown the Guyanese capital.
Of or pertaining to the inhabitants of Guyana; as, Guyanese followers of the religious cult leader died in Jonestown.

entry.def: A native or inhabitant of Guyana.
To guile.

entry.ety: Cf. Gules
entry.def: A roundlet of tincture sanguine, which is blazoned without mention of the tincture.

entry.ety: OP. gosillier, prob. orig., to pass through the throat; akin to F. gosier throat; cf. It. gozzo a bird's crop
entry.def: To swallow liquor greedily; to drink much or frequently.
entry.q: Those that came to guzzle in his wine cellar.
Well-seasoned bowls the gossip's spirits raise, Who, while she guzzles, chats the doctor's praise.
To fat the guzzling hogs with floods of whey.

entry.def: To swallow much or often; to swallow with immoderate gust; to drink greedily or continually; as, one who guzzles beer.
An insatiable thing or person.
entry.q: That sink of filth, that guzzle most impure.

entry.def: An immoderate drinker.

entry.ety: W. gwyniad a whiting, the name of various fishes, fr. gwyn white
entry.def: A fish (Coregonus ferus) of North Wales and Northern Europe, allied to the lake whitefish; -- called also powan, and schelly.
See Gayal.
See Jib.
See Gibe.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Gybed jībd; p. pr. & vb. n. Gybing
entry.ety: See Jibe
entry.def: To shift from one side of a vessel to the other; -- said of the boom of a fore-and-aft sail when the vessel is steered off the wind until the sail fills on the opposite side.

entry.ety: OF. guier; of German origin. See Guide, and cf. Guy
entry.def: To guide; to govern.
entry.q: Discreet enough his country for to gye.

cs.cd: a large vat in which wort ferments.

entry.ety: F. guiller to ferment. Cf. Guillevat
entry.def: Fermented wort used for making vinegar.
A genus of North American terrestrial orchids usually included in the genus Habenaria.
Same as Gimmal.

entry.ety: L. gymnasiarchus, Gr. gymnasi`archos; gymna`sion + 'a`rchein to govern: cf. F. gymnasiarque
entry.def: An Athenian officer who superintended the gymnasia, and provided the oil and other necessaries at his own expense.

entries.entry:
Gym*na"si*um jĭm*nā"zĭ*ŭm or jĭm*nā"zhĭ*ŭm; 277 n.; pl. E. Gymnasiums jĭm*nā"zĭ*ŭmz, L. Gymnasia jĭm*nā"zĭ*ȧ. L., fr. Gr. gymna`sion, fr. gymna`zein to exercise (naked), fr. gymo`s naked
A place or building where athletic exercises are performed; a school for gymnastics.
A school for the higher branches of literature and science; a preparatory school for the university; -- used esp. of German schools of this kind. More like ordinary schools of gymnasia than universities.

entry.ety: Gr. gymnasth`s a trainer of athletes: cf. F. gymnaste. See Gymnasium
entry.def: One who teaches or practices gymnastic exercises; the manager of a gymnasium; an athlete.

entry.ety: L. gymnasticus, Gr. gymnastiko`s: cf. F. gymnastique. See Gymnasium

sn.def: Pertaining to athletic exercises intended for health, defense, or diversion; -- originally said of games or exercises, as running, leaping, wrestling, throwing the discus, the javelin, etc.; in modern times more specifically applied to athletic exercises demonstrating balance and agility, such as tumbling, somersaulting, and bodily maneuvers performed on special equipment such as parallel bars or a balance beam; as, gymnastic exercises, contests, etc.
pertaining to disciplinary exercises for the intellect.

entry.def: A gymnast.
In a gymnastic manner.

sn.def: Athletic or disciplinary exercises; the art of performing gymnastic exercises.
Disciplinary exercises for the intellect or character.
Feats demonstrating a quick mental agility; as, mental gymnastics, verbal gymnastics .

entry.ety: L. gymnicus, Gr. gymniko`s: cf. F. gymnique. See Gymmasium
entry.def: Athletic; gymnastic.
entry.q: Have they not swordplayers, and every sort Of gymnic artists, wrestlers, riders, runners?

entry.def: Athletic exercise.

entry.ety: Gr. gymno`s naked. So called as coming from the Bare Hills, Maryland
entry.def: A hydrous silicate of magnesia.

entry.ety: NL. fr. Gr. gymno`s naked + blasta`nein to sprout
entry.def: The Athecata; -- so called because the medusoid buds are not inclosed in a capsule.
Of or pertaining to the Gymnoblastea.

entry.ety: Gr. gymno`s naked + karpo`s fruit
entry.def: Naked-fruited, the fruit either smooth or not adherent to the perianth.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. gymno`s naked + chro`a skin, body
entry.def: A division of Hydroidea including the hydra. See Hydra.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. gymno`s naked + kla`dos a branch
entry.def: A genus of leguminous plants; the Kentucky coffee tree. The leaves are cathartic, and the seeds a substitute for coffee.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. gymno`s naked + kw`ph an oar
entry.def: A group of transparent, free-swimming Annelida, having setæ only in the cephalic appendages.

entry.ety: Gr. gymno`s naked + ky`tos a hollow vessel
entry.def: A cytode without a proper cell wall, but with a nucleus.

entry.ety: Gr. gymno`s naked + E. cytode
entry.def: A cytode without either a cell wall or a nucleus.

entry.ety: Gr. gymno`s naked + 'odoy`s 'odo`ntos, tooth
entry.def: One of a group of plectognath fishes (Gymnodontes), having the teeth and jaws consolidated into one or two bony plates, on each jaw, as the diodonts and tetradonts. See Bur fish Globefish Diodon.

entry.ety: Gr. gymno`s naked + -gen
entry.def: One of a class of plants, so called by Lindley, because the ovules are fertilized by direct contact of the pollen. Same as Gymnosperm.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. gymno`s naked + glw^ssa tongue
entry.def: A division of gastropods in which the odontophore is without teeth.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. gymno`s naked + laimo`s the throat
entry.def: An order of Bryozoa, having no epistome.

entry.ety: NL. fr. Gr. gymno`s naked + nw^tos the back
entry.def: The order of fishes which includes the Gymnotus or electrical eel. The dorsal fin is wanting.

entry.ety: Gr. gymno`s naked + pai^s paido`s, a child
entry.def: Having young that are naked when hatched; psilopædic; -- said of certain birds.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. gymno`s naked + 'ofio`neos serpentlike
entry.def: An order of Amphibia, having a long, annulated, snakelike body. See Ophiomorpha.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. gymno`s naked + 'ofqalmo`s the eye
entry.def: A group of acalephs, including the naked-eyed medusæ; the hydromedusæ. Most of them are known to be the free-swimming progeny (gonophores) of hydroids.

entry.ety: Gr. gymno`s naked + pla`ssein to shape, mold
entry.def: A cell or mass of protoplasm devoid of an envelope, as a white blood corpuscle.

entry.ety: Gr. gymno`s naked + "ri`s "rino`s, the nose
entry.def: Having unfeathered nostrils, as certain birds.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. gymno`s naked + sw^ma sw`matos, the body
entry.def: One of the orders of Pteropoda. They have no shell.

entry.ety: Gr. gymnosofisth`s; gymno`s naked + sofisth`s philosopher; cf. F. gymnosophiste
entry.def: One of a sect of philosophers, said to have been found in India by Alexander the Great, who went almost naked, denied themselves the use of flesh, renounced bodily pleasures, and employed themselves in the contemplation of nature.
The doctrines of the Gymnosophists.
A plant that bears naked seeds (i. e., seeds not inclosed in an ovary), as the common pine and hemlock. Cf. Angiosperm.

entry.ety: Gr. gymno`spermos; gymno`s naked + spe`rma seed: cf. F. gymnosperme
entry.def: Having naked seeds, or seeds not inclosed in a capsule or other vessel.
Belonging to the class of plants consisting of gymnosperms.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. gymno`s naked + to`kos a bringing forth
entry.def: The Athecata.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. gymno`s naked + nw^tos the back: cf. F. gymnote
entry.def: A genus of South American fresh-water fishes, including the Gymnotus electricus, or electric eel. It has a greenish, eel-like body, and is possessed of electric power.
entry.q: One fearful shock, fearful but momentary, like that from the electric blow of the gymnotus.

entry.def: To begin. See Gin.

entry.ety: L., fr. Gr. gynaikei^on women's apartments, fr. gynh` a woman
entry.def: That part of a large house, among the ancients, exclusively appropriated to women.
The same as Gynecian.
Of or pertaining to gynecology; same as gynecological.
The branch of medicine that deals with the diseases and hygiene of women; same as gynecology.

entry.ety: Gr. gynaikei^on the women's apartments + fe`rein to bear
entry.def: A ventral canal or groove, in which the males of some diœcious trematodes carry the female. See Illust. of Hæmatozoa.

entry.ety: See Gynandrian
entry.def: A plant having the stamens inserted in the pistil.

entry.ety: NL. See Gynandrian
entry.def: A class of plants in the Linnæan system, whose stamens grow out of, or are united with, the pistil.

entry.ety: Gr. gy`nandros of doubtful sex; gynh` a woman + 'anh`r 'andro`s, man: cf. F. gynandre
entry.def: Having stamens inserted in the pistil; belonging to the class Gynandria.
An animal affected with gynandromorphism.

entry.ety: Gr. gynh` a woman, female + 'anh`r 'andro`s, a man, male + morfh` form
entry.def: An abnormal condition of certain animals, in which one side has the external characters of the male, and the other those of the female.
Affected with gynandromorphism.

entry.ety: Gr. gynh` a woman + E. anther
entry.def: Pertaining to an abnormal condition of the flower, in which the stamens are converted into pistils.

entry.ety: Gr. gynh` a woman + -archy
entry.def: Government by a woman.
See Gynæceum.

entry.ety: Gr. gynaikei^os
entry.def: Of or relating to women.

entry.ety: Gr. gynaikokrati`a; gynh` gynaiko`s, a woman + kratei^n to rule: cf. F. gynécocratie. Cf. Gynocracy
entry.def: Government by a woman, female power; gyneocracy.
Of or pertaining to gynecology.

entry.ety: Gr. gynh` gynaiko`s, a woman + -logy
entry.def: The science which treats of the structure and diseases of women.
See Gynecocracy.

entry.ety: Gr. gynh` a woman + latrei`a worship
entry.def: The adoration or worship of woman.
entry.q: The sentimental gyneolatry of chivalry, which was at best but skin-deep.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. gynh` a woman + fo`bos fear
entry.def: Hatred of women; repugnance to the society of women.
To begin. See Gin.

entry.ety: Gr. gynh` a woman, female + E. base
entry.def: A dilated base or receptacle, supporting a multilocular ovary.
Pertaining to, or having, a gynobase.

entry.ety: See Gynecocracy
entry.def: Female government; gynecocracy.
entry.q: The aforesaid state has repeatedly changed from absolute despotism to republicanism, not forgetting the intermediate stages of oligarchy, limited monarchy, and even gynocracy; for I myself remember Alsatia governed for nearly nine months by an old fishwoman.

entry.ety: Gr. gynh` a woman + E. diœcious
entry.def: Diœcious, but having some hermaphrodite or perfect flowers on an individual plant which bears mostly pistillate flowers.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. gynh` a woman + o'i^kos house
entry.def: The pistils of a flower, taken collectively. See Illust. of Carpophore.

entry.ety: Gr. gynh` woman, female + fe`rein to bear, produce: cf. F. gynophore

sn.def: The pedicel raising the pistil or ovary above the stamens, as in the passion flower.
One of the branches bearing the female gonophores, in certain Siphonophora.

entry.ety: Said to be a sportive application of Gr. gy`ps a vulture
entry.def: A college servant; -- so called in Cambridge, England; at Oxford called a scout.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: See Gypsum.

entry.ety: L. gypseus. See Gypsum
entry.def: Resembling or containing gypsum; partaking of the qualities of gypsum.
A gypsy. See Gypsy.

entry.ety: Gypsum + -ferous: cf. F. gypsifère
entry.def: Containing gypsum.
Gypseous.

entry.ety: Gypsum + -graphy
entry.def: The act or art of engraving on gypsum.

entry.ety: Gypsum + Gr. pla`ssein to mold
entry.def: A cast taken in plaster of Paris, or in white lime.

entry.ety: L. gypsum, Gr. gy`psos; cf. Ar. jibs plaster, mortar, Per. jabsīn lime
entry.def: A mineral consisting of the hydrous sulphate of lime (calcium). When calcined, it forms plaster of Paris. Selenite is a transparent, crystalline variety; alabaster, a fine, white, massive variety.

entries.entry:
Gyp"sy jĭp"s� n.; pl.Gypsies jĭp"sĭz. OE. Gypcyan, F. égyptien Egyptian, gypsy, L. Aegyptius. See Egyptian
gipsy gypsey
One of a vagabond race, whose tribes, coming originally from India, entered Europe in the 14th or 15th century, and are now scattered over Turkey, Russia, Hungary, Spain, England, etc., living by theft, fortune telling, horsejockeying, tinkering, etc. Cf. Bohemian Romany. Like a right gypsy, hath, at fast and loose, Beguiled me to the very heart of loss.
The language used by the gypsies.
A dark-complexioned person.
A cunning or crafty person. Colloq

cs.cd: a woman's or child's broad-brimmed hat, usually of straw or felt.
a small winch, which may be operated by a crank, or by a ratchet and pawl through a lever working up and down.

entry.def: Pertaining to, or suitable for, gypsies.
To play the gypsy; to picnic in the woods.

sn.def: The arts and practices or habits of gypsies; deception; cheating; flattery.
The state of a gypsy.

entries.entry:
Gyp"sy mothorGip"sy moth
By 1980 the range of habitat had advanced as far south as New Jersey, and by 1995 significant populations were found as far west as the Mississippi valley. Initial population surges along the advancing front of the inhabited area cause great damage due to defoliation of trees by the caterpillars, but over time predators, disease and other natural controlling factors tend to reduce the populations to levels not so injurious to local foliage. Much money and effort has been expended trying to control, slow, or limit the spread of gypsy moths in the United States.. A tussock moth (Lymantria dispar or Porthetria dispar or Ocneria dispar) native of the Old World, but accidentally introduced into eastern Massachusetts about 1869, where its caterpillars have done great damage to fruit, shade, and forest trees of many kinds. The male gypsy moth is yellowish brown, the female white, and larger than the male. In both sexes the wings are marked by dark lines and a dark lunule. The caterpillars, when full-grown, have a grayish mottled appearance, with blue tubercles on the anterior and red tubercles on the posterior part of the body, all giving rise to long yellow and black hairs. They usually pupate in July and the moth appears in August. The eggs are laid on tree trunks, rocks, etc., and hatch in the spring.

entry.def: A common hairy European perennial (Veronica officinalis) with pale blue or lilac flowers in axillary racemes.
A labiate plant (the Lycopus Europæus). Gypsies are said to stain their skin with its juice.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. gyro`s round + 'a`kanqa spine
entry.def: A genus of fossil fishes, found in Devonian and carboniferous strata; -- so named from their round, sculptured spines.

entry.ety: See Gyre

sn.def: Moving in a circular path or way; whirling; gyratory.
Pertaining to a gyrus, or convolution.

entry.def: Gyrating.

entry.ety: L. gyratus made in a circular form, p. p. of gyrare
entry.def: Winding or coiled round; curved into a circle; taking a circular course.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Gyrated jī"r�*tĕd; p. pr. & vb. n. Gyrating
entry.ety: L. gyratus, p. p. of gyrare to gyrate. See Gyre n.
entry.def: To revolve round a central point; to move spirally about an axis, as a tornado; to revolve.

entry.cs: Center of gyration. Mech See under Center. Radius of gyration the distance between the axis of a rotating body and its center of gyration. Rankine.

sn.def: The act of turning or whirling, as around a fixed center; a circular or spiral motion; motion about an axis; rotation; revolution.
sn.q: The gyrations of an ascending balloon.
If a burning coal be nimbly moved round in a circle, with gyrations continually repeated, the whole circle will appear like fire.

sn.def: One of the whorls of a spiral univalve shell.

entry.def: Moving in a circle, or spirally; revolving; whirling around.

entry.ety: L. gyrus, Gr. gy^ros, cf. gyro`s round
entry.def: A circular motion, or a circle described by a moving body; a turn or revolution; a circuit.
entry.q: Quick and more quick he spins in giddy gyres.
Still expanding and ascending gyres.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. gyrer girer. See Gyrate
entry.def: To turn round; to gyrate.
Abounding in gyres.

entry.ety: NL. fr. Gr. gyro`s round + 'egke`falos the brain
entry.def: The higher orders of Mammalia, in which the cerebrum is convoluted.

entry.ety: OE. gerfaucon, OF. gerfaucon, LL. gyrofalco, perh. fr. L. gyrus circle + falco falcon, and named from its circling flight; or cf. E. gier-eagle. See Gyre n. Falcon
entry.def: One of several species and varieties of large Arctic falcons, esp. Falco rusticolus and the white species Falco Islandicus, both of which are circumpolar. The black and the gray are varieties of the former. See Illust. of Accipiter.
See Gyrus.

entry.ety: See Garland
entry.def: To garland.
entry.q: Their hair loose and flowing, gyrlanded with sea grass.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. gyro`s round + 'odoy`s tooth
entry.def: A genus of extinct oölitic fishes, having rounded teeth in several rows adapted for crushing.

entry.ety: Gr. gy^ros circle, ring + go`nos fruit
entry.def: The petrified fruit of the Chara hispida, a species of stonewort. See Stonewort.

entry.ety: Gr. gy^ros circle + -oid + -al

sn.def: Spiral in arrangement or action.
Having the planes arranged spirally, so that they incline all to the right (or left) of a vertical line; -- said of certain hemihedral forms.
Turning the plane of polarization circularly or spirally to the right or left.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. gyro`s round + lepi`s scale
entry.def: A genus of ganoid fishes, found in strata of the new red sandstone, and the lias bone beds.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. gyroy^n to round, bend, fr. gyro`s round
entry.def: A turning round.

entry.ety: Gr. gy^ros ring, circle + -mancy: cf. F. gyromancie
entry.def: A kind of divination performed by drawing a ring or circle, and walking in or around it.

entry.ety: F. giron; of German origin. See Gore a piece of cloth
entry.def: A subordinary of triangular form having one of its angles at the fess point and the opposite side at the edge of the escutcheon. When there is only one gyron on the shield it is bounded by two lines drawn from the fess point, one horizontally to the dexter side, and one to the dexter chief corner.

entry.ety: F. gironné
entry.def: Covered with gyrons, or divided so as to form several gyrons; -- said of an escutcheon.

entry.ety: L. gyrare to revolve + E. pigeon
entry.def: A flying object simulating a pigeon in flight, when projected from a spring trap. It is used as a flying target in shooting matches.

entry.ety: Gr. gy^ros ring, circle + -scope

sn.def: A rotating wheel, mounted in a ring or rings, for illustrating the dynamics of rotating bodies, the composition of rotations, etc. It was devised by Professor W. R. Johnson, in 1832, by whom it was called the rotascope.

A form of the above apparatus, invented by M. Foucault, mounted so delicately as to render visible the rotation of the earth, through the tendency of the rotating wheel to preserve a constant plane of rotation, independently of the earth's motion.

entry.def: Pertaining to the gyroscope; resembling the motion of the gyroscope.

entry.ety: See Gyre
entry.def: Turned round like a crook, or bent to and fro.

entry.ety: Gr. gy^ros ring, circle + "ista`nai to cause to stand
entry.def: A modification of the gyroscope, consisting essentially of a fly wheel fixed inside a rigid case to which is attached a thin flange of metal for supporting the instrument. It is used in studying the dynamics of rotating bodies.
Of or pertaining to the gyrostat or to gyrostatics.
The doctrine or theory of the gyrostat, or of the phenomena of rotating bodies.

entries.entry:
‖Gy"rus jī"rŭs n.; pl.Gyri jī"rī. L. See Gyre n.
A convoluted ridge between grooves; a convolution; as, the gyri of the brain; the gyri of brain coral. See Brain.

entry.def: Guise.
Delirious; senselessly extravagant; as, the man is clean gyte .

entry.ety: Of Celtic origin; cf. W. gefyn, Ir. geibhionn, Gael. geimheal
entry.def: A shackle; especially, one to confine the legs; a fetter.
entry.q: Like a poor prisoner in his twisted gyves.
With gyves upon his wrist.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Gyved jīvd; p. pr. & vb. n. Gyving
entry.def: To fetter; to shackle; to chain.
entry.q: I will gyve thee in thine own courtship.
